name: Billionaires
bio: The World's Richest Man's fortune may be $10 billion less than it was two years ago at the height of the bull market, but his wealth still averages out to 62 cents of earnings for every second of Microsoft's existence. Chairman and chief software architect continues to push Microsoft ahead, past government inquiries and competitors. Still can't quite shake monopolist charges: vanquished Netscape, now under AOL umbrella, pursuing legal action, maintaining Microsoft fought unfairly during web browser war. In spare time said to enjoy touring African wilderness, but isn't taking very much time off: This past year led Microsoft on a half-billion dollar introduction of Xbox in an attempt to shoulder into videogame market; introduced updated operating system, Windows XP.

name: Billionaires
bio: After missing much of the tech-bubble, and its brutal fallout, Buffett's back-to-basics investing philosophy is commanding new respect. Berkshire Hathaway shares up 14% since Sept. 11, despite $2.4 billion blow against his reinsurance businesses following the terror attacks. Still, the Oracle of Omaha excels at finding stodgy but promising opportunities. Educated under value-guru Benjamin Graham at Columbia U., Buffett started first investment partnership at age 25. Later, with partner Charlie Munger, scouted out underpriced business to buy.

name: Billionaires
bio: Microsoft cofounder no longer on the board but still believed to hold large stake in company. Now concentarting on cable companies like Charter Communications and portfolio of Pacific Northwest sports teams.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founder of Oracle Corp., world's second-largest software company known for its enterprise-wide database products. Often-mercurial stances have populated Silicon Valley with a legion of talented, spurned lieutenants.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of Sam Walton (d. 1992), founder of Wal-Mart store chain, now world's biggest retailer. Jim is now chief executive of Arvest Group, a collection of community banks.

name: Billionaires
bio: The daughter of Wal-Mart founder Sam Walton (d. 1992) shares in family's massive stock holding. An active equestrian, she lives on a Texas ranch and avoids publicity.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of Sam Walton (d. 1992), founder of Wal-Mart store chain. Rob helped plan 1970 IPO, and has been a director since 1978. Now serves as chairman.

name: Billionaires
bio: The wealthiest individual investor outside the U.S. made headlines last October. That&#39s when then New York Mayor Rudolph Giuliani refused to accept the Prince&#39s $10 million gift for Sept. 11 victims because of written comments from the Prince suggesting the U.S. reexamine its policies in the Middle East. Undeterred, Prince Alwaleed continued to invest in U.S. stocks, boosting his Priceline.com stake to 5.4%. Nearly half his fortune is tied up in his 3.8% of Citigroup–his biggest home run investment to date.

name: Billionaires
bio: Johanna and children, Susanne and Stephan, are still holding tight to their lucrative 50% stake in luxury-car maker BMW. Despite the economic downturn, BMW had the most successful year in the group's history, achieving record sales, up 7%. The Quandt family also owns 19% of Gemplus, the world's leading smart-card vendor, and half of pharma and chemical producer Altana. Though exceedingly publicity-shy, they are well known for their philanthropy through the Herbert Quandt Foundation, established in 1980 to promote academic, scientific and cultural research and development throughout the world.

name: Billionaires
bio: Still the richest person in France. The 79-year-old daughter of L'Oreal founder Eugene Schueller remains adamant about keeping most of the company in private hands to ensure "stability." Despite limited pressure to reform L'Oreal's ownership structure, she will likely get her way.  Bettencourt controls L'Oreal via a 51% stake in Gesparal, a holding company that owns 53.7% of L'Oreal.  Nestle owns the remaining 49% of Gesparal.

name: Billionaires
bio: Microsoft's first business manager; hired by Gates in 1980, he took over chief executive reins from Gates in 2000. Must deal with slowing growth and massive cash holdings that have shareholders looking for dividend payments, a no-no in Microsoft corporate philosophy.

name: Billionaires
bio: The 76-year-old founder of home furnishings powerhouse Ikea, Kamprad saw worlwide sales jump almost 10% to $9.6 billion last year.   Recently given the green light to operate a freight train between Sweden and Germany, making it the first private company in Europe to operate its own cross-border rail service. (The once-a-day round-trip train will replace 50 trucks which ply the same route today.) Ikea fever has hit the U.K., where the enormous queues at the 11 English and Scottish branches have resulted in a spate of bad press. Kamprad is said to be "ashamed" of Ikea's customer service in Britain, but stores filled beyond capacity is a problem many would love to feel bad about.

name: Billionaires
bio: Mexico's Midas, Slim Helu is Latin America's richest man. The owner and privatizer of Mexico's biggest company, telephone monopoly Telmex, he also has stakes in the U.S. in Saks and Office Depot. Meanwhile, Slim is enjoying the high life at his new, modernist oceanfront digs on the Pacific Coast resort of Punta Ixtapa, dating his new, Mexican blueblood girlfriend Conchita Rionda, and socializing with glam-pal former Spanish prime minister Felipe Gonzales. A clever philanthropist as well as entrepreneur, Slim's foundations last year put up bail for 5,000 first-time offenders rotting in Mexican prisons.

name: Billionaires
bio: University of Texas dropout started Dell Computer from his dorm room in 1984. Became the world's largest computer seller using a direct sales method. A cut in prices has eased the pain of the industry-wide slump in computer sales.

name: Billionaires
bio: Following the death of their father, Gad, in 2000, Kirsten and brothers, Jorn and Finn, have carried on the family tradition at packaging giant Tetra Laval, with all three holding seats on the board and Jorn working in management.  Kirsten's board duties still allow enough time to pursue her true passion, breeding championship racehorses. That may be for the best, since Tetra was dealt an enormous blow in October, when its acquisition of French plastic bottling company Sidel was quashed by the European Commission.  The commission nixed the deal on the grounds the merger would have strengthened Tetra's already dominant position in the market. Too bad, since Tetra Laval had already purchased the controlling shares in Sidel for $1.5 billion. The company is holding on to the shares while it appeals the EC's decision.

name: Billionaires
bio: With Barbara Cox Anthony, one of two sisters who inherited vast media empire started by father James M. Cox. Today Cox Communications owns 16 daily newspapers (incl. flagship Atlanta Constitution), cable systems (6 million subscribers), radio and television stations.

name: Billionaires
bio: Asia's richest and most powerful man.  At home, Li Ka-shing 73, controls electricity generation, cellular phone service. In mainland China his companies are a dominant force in infrastructure development, having built more than 600 km of roads and bridges. These days Li's ambition is taking on a global perspective. A string of recent acquisitions has made him the operator of the world's largest network of ports, with 29 container ports spanning 15 countries. Li also has ambitions to offer wireless Web service to more than 160 million users and has spent millions on 3G licenses in Austria, Australia, Sweden, Italy and the U.K. He went hunting for bargains in the U.S. last year admid the economic downturn and picked up a 38% stake in Priceline and a joint majority stake in Global Crossing. Li, once a poor immigrant, got his start selling plastic flowers in Hong Kong in the 1950s.

name: Billionaires
bio: Hong Kong property barons. The Kwok brothers inherited property business after death of father Kwok Tak-seng in 1990 at the age of 79. Some of the brothers' attempts to diversify beyond property haven't met much success. Their money-losing cell phone operation, SmarTone, struggles as the price war between the mobile phone carriers in Hong Kong heats up. Internet venture SuneVision, which provides Internet services to corporations, is also unprofitable. All three are Western-educated: Eldest Walter holds a master of civil engineering from the University of London; Thomas, an M.B.A. from the University of London; and youngest Raymond, an M.B.A from Harvard. Thomas and Walter are avid runners and regular participants in the annual China Coast Marathon sponsored by their company Sun Hung Kai.

name: Billionaires
bio: Virtually unknown a year ago, this unassuming Spaniard strode into public view when his fashion company Inditex went public last May. Now holds the title of one of the richest self-made entrepreneurs in Europe.  Invested the $1.7 billion in net proceeds in two new investment companies. In the meantime, his $2.3 billion (revenues) textile chain continues to expand, adding a new lingery line (Oysho) and opening stores in Switzerland and Iceland, with Italy soon to come. He still refuses to wear ties.

name: Billionaires
bio: With John Fraklyn Mars and Jacqueline Badger Mars, three siblings who inherited food giant Mars Inc.: candy (Snickers, M&Ms, Milky Way), pet food (Whiskas), prepared food (Uncle Ben's Rice).

name: Billionaires
bio: With Forrest Edward Mars and John Franklyn Mars, one of three siblings who inherited food giant Mars, Inc.: Candy (Snickers, M&Ms, Milky Way), pet food (Whiskas), prepared food (Uncle Ben's Rice).

name: Billionaires
bio: With Forrest Edward Mars and Jacqueline Badger Mars, three siblings who inherited food giant Mars Inc.: candy (Snickers, M&Ms, Milky Way), pet food (Whiskas), prepared food (Uncle Ben's Rice).

name: Billionaires
bio: Abigail and Ned Johnson, daughter and father, run Fidelity Investments, which shrank 3% in 2001 to $883 billion in assets under management. Still plenty to do: Abigail appointed president of Fidelity Management & Research Company in May. Ned chief executive since 1972.

name: Billionaires
bio: Bertarelli was one of Europe's youngest CEOs when he succeeded his father at Geneva-based pharamceutical company Serono in 1996 at the age of 30. Lauded for transforming a relatively traditional drug firm into one of the world's largest biotech companies, with $1.4 billion in sales last year. Look for sales of Rebif, the blockbuster multiple sclerosis treatment, to spike this year if Serono gets its long-awaited FDA approval. It's not a sure thing yet, though, since "orphan drug" patents held by Serono competitors will keep Rebif out of U.S. pharmacies until they expire next year. When he's not at work, Bertarelli is a champion yachtsman, funding "Alinghi" to race in next year's America's Cup in New Zealand.

name: Billionaires
bio: Despite pushing 80, Viacom CEO still looking for way to overtake AOL Time Warner to become world's biggest media mogul. But internal strife with CBS' Mel Karmazin threatens to shake investor confidence. Recently used Viacom-owned Simon & Schuster to publish autobiography "A Passion to Win." Started at father's drive-in movie business 1954. Viacom empire now includes CBS, Paramount, MTV, Blockbuster Video, Infinity Broadcasting. Sumner remains CEO; day-to-day work mostly done by Karmazin.

name: Billionaires
bio: In 1995 Rausing sold his 50% stake in packaging giant Tetra Laval to brother Gad for a reported $7 billion. He came out of his short-lived retirement last year to invest in Ecolean, an upstart packaging company. It's hardly a sure thing. Ecolean's sales last year were $8.6 million.  Should Ecolean pick up steam, it will go head-to-head against his now-deceased brother's empire. In his spare time, Rausing tools around his 900-acre East Sussex estate in vintage cars, kicking back with wife, Marit, and dog, Tess.

name: Billionaires
bio: Prime minister of Italy, elected in May 2001 for the second time. His first term lasted only 7 months. Self-made, built the largest commercial broadcaster in Italy, Finivest. Now is under pressure to divest some businesses because of potential conflicts of interest. Secured bipartisan support for Italy’s participation in the American-led military strikes in Afghanistan. Berlusconi is often self-mocking about his admiration for all things American: “I am whatever side America is on, even before I know what it is.” Upset his European partners by resisting to honor the European Union’s anticorruption law in Italy, a move that was seen as self-serving, given corruption charges currently pending against him. Later reversed his position. Owns soccer club A.C. Milan.

name: Billionaires
bio: Arnault took some heat in September for whining publicly about the negative effect the Sept. 11 attacks had on LVMH’s bottom line. But even before 9/11, the luxury goods giant was off balance, missing earnings targets. Since last May the value of Arnault’s stake in LVMH has fallen nearly $2 billion. One bright spot: In September Arnault settled his long-running feud with Francois Pinault over control of Gucci. Under the terms of the deal, LVMH agreed to sell all its Gucci shares for $1.9 billion. Meanwhile, the tech slowdown continued to spell trouble for Arnault’s Europatweb internet incubator. He closed the venture down in February.

name: Billionaires
bio: His Quantum Fund hedge fund is among the largest in the world at $12 billion, most of it belonging to the Soros family. Recently hired Julian Robertson protege Robert Bishop to run fund after a seven month search.

name: Billionaires
bio: Last year's steady rise in real estate prices in London's tony West End means the Duke of Westminister a.k.a. Gerald Cavendish Grosvenor, owner of the fabled 300 golden acres in Mayfair and Belgravia, fared much better than many of his fellow billionaires. Grosvenor is currently modernizing the 300 acres by putting in IT infrastructure.

name: Billionaires
bio: Lived in an orphanage for much of his childhood. Started making tools for eyeglasses frames. Created eyewear empire Luxottica, the world’s largest designer and manufacturer of high-quality eyeglasses frames. The group also includes Ray-Ban, U.S. optical chain LensCrafters and recently acquired U.S. retailer Sunglass Hut. Owns a stake in Unicredito, Italy’s third-largest bank. Had his fifth child last year. Eldest son, Claudio runs U.S.-based Retail Brand Alliance, which owns Casual Corner and now Brooks Brothers.

name: Billionaires
bio: Runs $21 billion (sales) Otto Versand, the world's largest mail-order company. Founded by father Werner Otto in 1949, the company got its start as a 14-page catalogue offering 28 styles of shoes. Today it offers 21,000 products in more than 1,300 pages. With Internet sales more than tripling in 2000 to $945 million and continuing to grow in 2001 (figures have not yet been published), the group says that it is now the Web's second biggest consumer retailer, after Amazon.com. Together with his father and four siblings he owns 65% of Otto Versand, over 50% of home furnishings chain Crate & Barrel, U.S. catalog retailer Spiegel and a $1.5 billion real estate portfolio in the U.S., Canada and Germany. Like fellow billionaire Rolf Gerling, Michael Otto is a passionate environmentalist who promotes environmentally friendly products in his catalogue and supports several foundations for the preservation of clean water.

name: Billionaires
bio: Stanford graduate is India’s leading software entrepreneur. His Bombay Stock Exchange-traded flagship Wipro, the country’s largest listed IT company, is weathering the tech downturn. Premji’s 84% stake worth $6.4 billion makes him the richest resident Indian. A workaholic, he is building a new house right next to Wipro’s campus.

name: Billionaires
bio: Head of country's second-biggest satellite provider, EchoStar, now in midst of buying the biggest one, DirecTV, from General Motors in $26 billion deal. Former Frito-Lay financial analyst started delivering to large-dish rural residents in 1980. Now, through Dish Network, provides more than 500 channels to over 5 million customers.

name: Billionaires
bio: Intel Corp. cofounder and author of oft-cited Moore's Law that microprocessor power doubles every 18 months. Has given away half of fortune in recent years.

name: Billionaires
bio: A recent run of bad luck for the casino and movie mogul: ex-wife making public, expensive child-support claims; attempt to sell MGM movie studio has yet to pan out. Began investing career building up a charter airline with surplus aircraft after WWII, sold for $104 million profit.

name: Billionaires
bio:
With his brothers, runs $3.1 billion (revenues) Mohammed Abdulmohsin Al-Kharafi & Sons, a contracting group. Trying to attract European tourists to their Disneyesque Port Galib on Egypt's Red Sea coast. The fledgling resort's French-managed airport began accepting commercial flights from Europe in late 2001. Project cost is estimated at $2 billion.
Eldest brother Jassim is chairman, but younger brother Nasser is president and the one considered to make things run. Sister Faiza Al-Kharafi is a senior academic and president of Kuwait University. Brothers travel often to London. Younger generation make jaunts to U.S. hot spots like Los Angeles, Miami, New York and elsewhere.

name: Billionaires
bio: Sneaker giant's stock took dive last February after earnings came in short, but Nike has surged back like a distance runner, hitting a new 52-week high in January. With net worth of $5.7 billion, cofounder Knight hits new high himself; remains chairman, CEO, president and whipping-boy-in-chief for opponents of low-wage manufacturing in Asia. Stopped donating to alma mater U. of Oregon after it joined an antisweatshop organization that it's since left. Knight founded Nike in 1968 with his former track coach, Bill Bowerman (d. 1999), designer of waffle-sole running shoe.

name: Billionaires
bio: Media baron walked away from efforts to buy DirecTV from General Motors. Now he's turned his focus on Europe, possibly making a play for the ailing German media empire of Leo Kirch. In the U.S., Murdoch bought Chris-Craft Industries' stations last year from Herbert Siegel, giving Murdoch access to 40% of the viewing public. Not bad for a man who started with one small paper in his home town of Adelaide, Australia. Now the septuagenarian, and U.S. citizen, is said to be grooming eldest son, Lachlan, to inherit his media empire.

name: Billionaires
bio: Great-grandson of the founder of BASF. Orchestrated the sale of  pharmaceutical firms Boehringer Mannheim and DePuy Inc. to Roche in 1997 for $11 billion. Sale of his share netted him $4.4 billion. Retired, he now lives in Bermuda with his fourth wife, Heidemarie.

name: Billionaires
bio: Despite a mixed year for retailers, Persson's flagship company, hip clothier Hennes & Mauritz, met its sales forecasts. But the outlook remains challenging, thanks to the emergence of Spain's Inditex, another trendy peddler of microminis and capri pants. H&M's expansion into the U.S. seen as a bruise, as American customers haven't warmed up to the store formats, which hawk clothes for men, women and children under one roof. Analysts gripe that H&M "isn't what it used to be," particularly when compared to the streamlined management of Inditex. Despite company assertions to the contrary, H&M may be late in its stated goal of opening 60 U.S. stores by 2003.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founded two giants: Home builder Kaufman & Broad (now KB Home) and insurer Sun America. Sold latter to AIG 1998 for $18 billion, still sits on board. Now focuses on "venture philanthropy," reforming urban public schools, revitalizing L.A.'s downtown. Serious art collector.

name: Billionaires
bio: This real estate baron has been hit hard by Hong Kong’s soft real estate prices. Net profits of his Henderson Land fell 25% last year. Another sticky point for investors is the 73-year-old Lee’s seeming reluctance to pass the baton. If longevity is a family trait, Lee has quite some time left.  His father just passed away at age 106.

name: Billionaires
bio: Anschutz made his money in oil, then added billions by branching into railroads like Union Pacific. Railroad right-of-ways led to the laying of fiber optic networks and the formation of Qwest Communications, which accounts for the bulk of his wealth; also accounts for his net worth's plunge from $15 billion to $5 billion. Of late he's been buying movie theater chains, sports teams and a stake in London's maligned Millennium Dome. He also plans to brings C.S. Lewis novels to the big screen.

name: Billionaires
bio: The media Bolivar. Cisneros continues to dream of a borderless Latin American media market. The dream is coming true. One of the founders and still a 19% shareholder in the profitable U.S. Spanish-language network Univision, he also owns a host of TV and radio networks in Venezuela, Chile and Argentina, as well as large stakes in AOL Latin America and DirecTV Latin America. From his Venezuelan station, Venevision, Cisneros sells his country's signature soap operas (telenovelas) to 60 countries across the globe. For fun Cisneros likes to go bone-fishing off the Venezuelan coast, sometimes with buddy George Bush.

name: Billionaires
bio: Haefner, 91, cemented his ties with Computer Associates in 2001 when he stood behind the company’s embattled management team, using his 21% stake to help fend off a hostile shareholder challenge from U.S. investor Sam Wyly.  "After what [founder and chairman] Charles Wang and CA have done for me," Haefner wrote in a June letter to Wyly explaining his position, "I cannot do otherwise."  His loyalty has paid off.  The value of his stake has increased 15% since last year though new accounting allegations might reverse that trend. Age hasn&#39t lessened his zeal for fast horses or fast cars, either. Haefner owns AMAG, Switzerland&#39s only licensed dealer for Volkswagens, Audis and Porsches. He also owns a racehorse stud farm in Ireland.

name: Billionaires
bio: Started arbitrage career with $4,000 Army poker winnings, borrowed $400,000 to buy a seat on the New York Stock Exchange in 1968. The archetypal 1980s takeover artist, he scored big with Texaco, ACF, TWA and USX. In recent years made a bundle shorting Priceline and going long on GM. Now trying his hand at laser-vision-correction-trailblazer VISX and industrial services firm Philip Services. Looking to buy 40% of troubled drug maker ImClone.

name: Billionaires
bio: With older brother Samuel Irving (Si) Newhouse, inherited sprawling magazine and newspaper empire Advance Publications. Si runs Conde Nast magazine group; Don oversees newspapers (Newark Star-Ledger, Cleveland Plain Dealer).

name: Billionaires
bio: With younger brother Donald, inherited sprawling magazine and newspaper empire Advance Publications. "Si" runs Conde Nast magazine division: Vogue, Vanity Fair, New Yorker.

name: Billionaires
bio: Robert and Thomas, uncle and nephew, run family empire, recently blemished by investment in now-insolvent Superior Bank. Robert and brother Jay (d. 1999) inherited business started by grandfather Nicholas in 1902. Robert stepped down as chief executive of Marmon Group conglomerate after 49 years. Jay's son Thomas heads Hyatt hotel chain. Their other holding, Royal Caribbean Cruises, merging with P&O Princess Cruises.

name: Billionaires
bio: Lost his father at age 10. Founded a small sweater company with sister Giuliana in 1955. Still runs the now-$1.9  billion fashion group Benetton, best known for its edgy ads. Along with his brothers and sister, has moved into other industries. Was a 40% minority partner with Pirelli in one of Italy’s biggest deals of last year, the acquisition of Olivetti for $6.4 billion. Other holdings: Autogrill, food catering group; Autostrade, Europe’s largest publicly listed highway system and Bene Stabili, a real estate holding company.

name: Billionaires
bio: Serge, the chairman and CEO of Groupe Dassault, is the son of Marcel Dassault, founder of Dassault Aviation. The family name has been associated with top-line military and corporate jets for more than a half-century.  Fighter jets like the Mirage and Rafale patrol the skies of a diverse range of countries, from France to Chile to India.  On the civilian side, the Falcon corporate jet has been a top seller since its introduction in the 1970s. But over the last decade, Serge, the family patriarch, has expanded the brand into multimedia services, real estate, communications and an investment vehicle that plugs money into an eclectic range of high-tech companies, from software developers to fish farms. At least three other Dassault family members hold senior management positions throughout the Groupe.

name: Billionaires
bio: He and John Sall met at N.C. State, teamed to develop statistical analysis program. SAS now world's largest privately held software maker with $1.2 billion in sales. Midway Airlines venture filed for bankruptcy, now back in the air.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of banker Wilhelm von Finck, who founded insurance giant Allianz. Lives in tax-haven Switzerland, where he oversees a fortune based on stakes in insurance, mining and chemical companies, a retail chain, property rental and leasing and a sizable portion of Swiss restaurant and hotel chain Moevenpick.

name: Billionaires
bio: Creator of Web auction site Ebay. Created company in 1995 so girlfriend could trade Pez candy dispensers. Took company public 1998, now concentrating on using his new wealth to support charitable causes such as education, housing and health care. Company run by Meg Whitman.

name: Billionaires
bio: The financial news and data entrepreneur spent a record $70 million in his  contentious run for New York City Mayor against Democrat Mark Green. Now that he's won, the hard work is just beginning: Must grapple with rebuilding Twin Towers site and fixing budget deficits even his kingly fortune couldn't fill, all in the shadow of Rudy Giuliani. In the meantime, has been looking to unload his eponymous company for the unlikely amount of $10 billion.

name: Billionaires
bio: The young heir to the gigantic Polar bottling and food-processing company, Mendoza has presided over several years of growth. Polar's leading position in much of the country's food industries, including cooking oils, ice cream and rice, remains largely unchallenged. But Polar has recently been bloodied a bit in its signature beer business, where upstart Cisneros brand Regional has stolen market share by targeting women and light-beer drinkers.

name: Billionaires
bio: Cochairman and cofounder of SAP, one of the world's largest software firms. SAP software can manage all aspects of a company's internal operations from human resources to tracking inventories. Despite weaknesses in the world software market, SAP was able to increase sales by 17% in 2001 to $6.3 billion.  License sales in the U.S., however, felt the combined brunt of the recession and Sept 11, dropping 32% in the third quarter last year. Competes against Oracle in business and leisure. An avid golfer and world-class sailor, Plattner is sponsoring the New Zealand boat in the America's Cup, one of whose challengers will be Larry Ellison of Oracle.

name: Billionaires
bio: Inherited control of Dutch brewery giant Heineken from her father, Alfred Heineken, who died in January at age 78.  She's a relative unknown since her father was a jealous guardian of his family's privacy.  He had good reason to keep the public away:  In 1983 he was kidnapped and held for ransom for three weeks.   Charlene, who lives in London, now retains her father's majority stake in Heineken Holdings, the semipublic holding company that controls the brewery.  In the last years of Alfred's life, there were grumblings that the family's 25% controlling stake was an anachronistic weight holding back Heineken's ability to grow.  With a younger generation now in control, questions about changing or reducing the family's involvement will surely resurface.  But so far neither Charlene, nor her husband, who sits on Heineken's supervisory board, have indicated any plans to ditch Alfred's game plan.

name: Billionaires
bio: Owns 70% of privately held Gerling Konzern, one of the world's largest industrial insurers, which has expanded its world coverage to include such countries as Kazakhstan, China, Iran and Vietnam. Company expects to take an estimated $200 million hit on 2001 earnings because of the Sept. 11 terrorist attack in New York (about 6% of annual premium volume). Gerling himself is not active in the business but lives in Switzerland, where he pursues his passionate interest in the environment and heads the Gerling Academy for Risk Research, a think tank that studies the industrial world's impact on the environment.

name: Billionaires
bio: Abigail and Ned Johnson, daughter and father, run Fidelity Investments, which shrank 3% in 2001 to $883 billion in assets under management. Still plenty to do: Abigail appointed president of Fidelity Management & Research Company in May. Ned chief executive since 1972.

name: Billionaires
bio: Like most fortunes that depend on the stock market, Sainsbury's net worth fell last year. The 8.5% dip, though, wasn't too sharp because the eponymous family grocery business reported strong Christmas sales and has for the first time in six years started to steal customers back from archrival Tesco. David Sainsbury retained his post as minister of science under the new Labour government.

name: Billionaires
bio: The privately held House of Chanel is jointly owned by the Wertheimer brothers--grandsons of Chanel founder Pierre Wertheimer.  But it's Alain who runs the company and has presided over the acquisition of several non-Chanel brands, including Eres lingerie, Tanner Krolle saddles and leather goods, and Holland & Holland, a British gunsmith. Designer Karl Lagerfeld was also hired on his watch to keep the Chanel name synonymous with classic chic.  The brothers also dabble in wine, owning Chateau Canon and Chateau Rausan Segla.

name: Billionaires
bio: Runs George Weston Ltd., one of North America's largest bakers. In January Weston announced the $610 million sale of its Oroweat division to Mexican food concern Grupo Bimbo. Proceeds will pay down debt from last year's $1.8 billion acquisition of Bestfoods. Controlling stakes in Canada's top grocer, Loblaw's, as well as high-fashion retailers Holt, Renfrew and Brown Thomas. In England family also runs Associated British Foods. This year took England's prestigious luxury store Fortnum & Mason private. Family's W. Garfield Weston Foundation supports the Canadian Merit Scholarship Foundation and the Nature Conservancy of Canada. Weston's wife, Hillary, Ontario's lieutenant governor, follows suit by donating entire salary to support youth-related programs. Galen splits his time between Ontario and Vero Beach, Fla., where he attends to ritzy residential developments Orchid Island and Windsor.

name: Billionaires
bio: The sons of Kenneth Colin Irving, one of Canada's pioneer industrialists, stay firmly rooted in the Old Economy. The family owns Canada's largest oil refinery, over 3 million acres of timberland in New Brunswick, Nova Scotia and Maine, and a large trucking and shipping business. Their Cavendish farms produce over 1 billion pounds of potatoes for french fries each year. Extended their reach farther west last year with purchase of Aviko USA, a North Dakota  potato-processing plant. Family not impervious to recession: folded one of its four newspapers last year. Third generation of Irvings--most notably James D. and Kenneth--active in the family businesses.

name: Billionaires
bio: Unassuming billionaire, Kuok trades and processes huge quantities of edible oils and grains in Southeast Asia and China. Started trading sugar and rice in the 1950s in Malaysia; traded with China as early as 1960. Also owns a shipping line, a chain of luxury hotels and holds a Coca-Cola bottling franchise in mainland China. Stubbornly shuns publicity. "Tall trees experience strong winds," he says. Loves crystal: His Shangri-La Hotel in Hong Kong has more than 700 crystal chandeliers costing up to $11,000 each. These days sons manage day-to-day operations of his vast empire.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founder of nation's largest discount broker has weathered the end of the public's love affair with day trading. Company adding "full service" arms. With takeover rumors swirling, reasserting influence after taking backseat to Co-Chief Executive David Pottruck. As market collapsed, shouldered blame for overspending on Internet. Back as TV pitchman.

name: Billionaires
bio: Publicity-shy Irvine Co. chief keeps tight rein over vast properties in Orange County, L.A., San Diego and Silicon Valley. Built first house in 1958. Sold home building company to International Paper in 1970 for $34 million. Purchased Irvine Ranch in 1977 with Al Taubman, Herb Allen and Max Fisher. Became majority owner in 1983. Irvine Co. largest landowner in Orange County.

name: Billionaires
bio: After making his first billion in the music business, Geffen started a new entertainment outfit, Dreamworks SKG, with partners Jeffrey Katzenberg and Steven Spielberg. Music business doing so-so, but motion pictures unit on a tear: "Saving Private Ryan," "Gladiator," "American Beauty." Look for the studio to walk away with another Oscar for best picture this year for "A Beautiful Mind."

name: Billionaires
bio: Places bets on the future. Outsmarted rivals by taking an early chance on the cell phone market in Turkey. His 43% stake in Turkcell, the country's leading mobile-phone service, dominates his fortune. It'll take years before new entrants begin to chip away at Turkcell's 65% market share. Accused of inflating subscriber numbers before raising $1.6 billion in  Turkcell's 2000 IPO. Owns Superonline, Turkey's leading Internet service provider (ISP) and portal. Could gain market share now that ISP competitor IXIR has shut down and transferred all of its subscribers (150,000) to SuperOnline.

name: Billionaires
bio: Secretive Beanie Babies mastermind reinvesting plush toy dollars into plush hotels: nearly $500 million Four Seasons Hotels in New York and Santa Barbara.

name: Billionaires
bio: Though Perot handed over day-to-day control of data management company Perot Systems to his son, Ross Perot Jr., the two-time presidential contender remains chairman. Perot Jr. also runs Hillwood, a Dallas-area real estate development company. This year completed construction on pro basketball's Dallas Mavericks home arena, the American Airlines Center.

name: Billionaires
bio: Shares the ownership of $24 billion (sales) food retailer Tengelmann Group, one of Germany's largest employers, with his three sons, Karl-Erivan, Georg and Christian. In the U.S. the family owns 57% of A&P supermarkets.  The 135-year-old Tengelmann has been restructuring in an effort to offset the effects of a slack German retail market and increased industry consolidation. Haub, who owns property in the U.S. and whose sons are American citizens, took out full-page ads in various German newspapers speaking out in solidarity with the U.S. after the Sep 11 attack.

name: Billionaires
bio: Volatile mix of high costs, heavy debt and lackluster markets are eating away at privately held chemical empire. He founded Huntsman Chemical 1982. Now focusing on higher-margin specialty chemicals. A devout Mormon and two-time cancer survivor, Huntsman gives generously to Mormon, Catholic charities. Though busy trying to restore business empire to former grandeur, the Utah native found time to carry Olympic torch on its way to the Winter Games in Salt Lake City.

name: Billionaires
bio: Talk about a tough year: "Fired" by retiring AOL Time Warner boss Gerald Levin; divorced from Jane Fonda; criticized for impolitic comments about "bravery" of Sept. 11 terrorists. Even the market for his bison soured. But AOL Time Warner’s largest individual shareholder has even more reason to scream: AOL stock fell nearly 60% in value, slicing $5 billion from his worth. With Levin gone and Turner back in, expect the "Mouth of the South" to make more noise if things don’t improve.

name: Billionaires
bio: The man who charmed Sam Walton into expanding south of the border is still reaping rewards from the deal. His retail chain Cifra entered into a joint venture with Wal-Mart in the early 1990s. Spanish-born Arango is no longer active in the company, since renamed Wal-Mex. But he continues to hold a large and--thanks to excellent management that produced a 20% rise in profits last year--steadily appreciating stake in Wal-Mex.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chief executive of Carnival, the world's largest cruise ship operator. Trying to foil merger between P&O Princess and Royal Caribbean. Arison inherited firm from father Ted (d. 1999) and expanded. Boasts over 45 ships, expanding ports to include Alaska, New Orleans and Tampa. Increased prices of flagship line and amassed almost $1 billion in capital this year by reorganizing assets to combat travel industry's economic crisis. Also owns NBA's Miami Heat franchise.

name: Billionaires
bio: After the death of his brother Jose in 2001, Antonio became the nominal head of Votorantim, Brazil's largest private conglomerate, with 2000 net revenues of $2.65 billion. The group is big in pulp and paper, cement and aluminum. It entered the U.S. and Canadian markets through a $720 million acquisition of cement assets from European giant Lafarge.

name: Billionaires
bio: Turned around General Dynamics after buying large stake in company, booting managers. Now trying to get appliance maker Maytag to rebound. Son of Chicago financier Henry Crown (d. 1990); Lester remains active in the City of the Big Shoulders, recently brokering a contoversial agreement to expand O'Hare Airport.

name: Billionaires
bio: Sold the last 5% of his Massa chain of German department stores in 1994 but kept the underlying real estate. Also owns four luxury hotels in Switzerland and several buildings in New York. Retired, he now lives at the Hotel Tschuggen in Arosa, Switzerland, one of his five-star hotels.

name: Billionaires
bio: Family patriarch John Latsis made his fortune in shipping and can still be found entertaining British royals aboard his lavish yacht, The Alexander. His son, Spiro, a banker, has shifted the family fortune away from shipping and into banking. A small tanker fleet still flies the Latsis colors, but the bulk of the extended family's wealth comes from its ownership of EFG Bank Group, an international commercial and private banking consortium based in Switzerland.

name: Billionaires
bio: With brother, inherited commercial real estate empire from his father in 1993. Runs Mori Trust Group, which made two significant purchases recently: it bought 10% of Fujita Kanko, Japan's second-biggest hotel chain last year, and 20% of the Loft variety store chain this year.

name: Billionaires
bio: His bubble stock is still floating: shares of his 4th-generation gum empire are up 22% in the last year. Bill Jr. took over company 1999 after father died unexpectedly while recuperating from fractured hip and divorcing third wife. Settled estate battle, reinvigorated company: new product lines, new blood in top jobs. "I see my role as taking a late-19th-century company and bringing it into the 21st century with guns blazing."

name: Billionaires
bio: Despite her low profile, Israel's wealthiest citizen recently made headlines on speculation that she may bid for Bezeq, Israel's state-owned telecommunications giant on the verge of privatization. Inherited her father Ted Arison's Israeli operations, plus owns $2 billion worth of Carnival Corp., the Miami-based leisure cruise line run by brother Micky. Carnival is embroiled in an increasingly hostile battle with Royal Caribbean for the acquisition of P&O Princess Cruises. Arison Dorsman continues to promote Matan, the philanthropy she modeled after United Way.

name: Billionaires
bio: Africa’s richest man derives most of his wealth from diamonds. The third generation of his family to head De Beers, he led a successful $19 billion bid to take the group private last year in one of the largest corporate deals in African history. His family now owns 45%. After several robust years the diamond market was dulled by an economic downturn and the effects of Sept. 11. In November the family sold 10 million shares in mining giant Anglo American, which owns 45% of De Beers. Still holds a 3% stake. A large landowner in Zimbabwe, the family is under pressure from that country’s government to give back land. Pilots his own helicopter to visit his prized game reserve, which he plans to turn into “the premier eco-tourist destination in southern Africa.”

name: Billionaires
bio: The colorful Itoyama was a member of parliament from 1974 to 1996. Inherited a fortune made up of golf courses in Japan and New Jersey. As the largest individual shareholder in Japan Airlines, gained notoriety in recent years for strongly criticizing its management at annual shareholders meetings. His personal life was tumultuous last year as his pregnant daughter had a shot-gun wedding. Nonetheless, having recently turned 60, he says he is very happy to have become a grandfather.

name: Billionaires
bio: The family's electricity and hotel business was founded more than 100 years ago in Shanghai by Elly Kadoorie, a Jewish Iraqi from Baghdad. Elly's sons Lawrence and Horace Kadoorie ran the business in Hong Kong  before handing it over to Lawrence's son Michael Kadoorie. As chairman of Hongkong & Shanghai Hotels and CLP Holdings, Michael oversees the family investments there. CLP Holdings, a major supplier of electricity in Hong Kong, is aggressively making forays into China. The family's chain of upscale hotels under the Peninsula name is well known for its architecture and prestigious addresses. The Kadoorie family are renowned philanthropists: funded the construction of dams, bridges, agricultural projects and schools in Hong Kong benefiting thousands of victims of war. Their Kadoorie Farm & Botanical Garden spends millions to protect rare orchids and butterflies.

name: Billionaires
bio: Brothers Charles and David run Koch Industries, the $35 billion oil conglomerate founded by father Fred. Energy trading joint venture with power company Entergy in Houston stands to gain some business from Enron implosion. Last year Charles and David buried the hatchet with brother William, who years before accused the company of stealing oil from federal lands and cheating him out of his share in the family business.

name: Billionaires
bio: Brothers Charles and David run Koch Industries, the $35 billion oil conglomerate founded by father Fred. Energy trading joint venture with power company Entergy in Houston stands to gain some business from Enron implosion. Last year Charles and David buried the hatchet with brother William, who years before accused the company of stealing oil from federal lands and cheating him out of his share in the family business.

name: Billionaires
bio: Francois Pinault's retail juggernaut, Pinault-Printemps-Redoute, sells just about everything, from Gucci bags to lumber to cars in Africa.  Some shareholders think a tighter focus might produce higher returns, but majority shareholder Pinault and his CEO Serge Weinberg are committed to the grab bag approach, saying retail is retail. PPR's U.S. sales fell more than 15% in the months after September 11, but the company finished 2001 with consolidated sales up 12%. Despite that good news, Pinault's 34% stake has lost almost half of its value, a difference of some $4 billion from his net worth last year.

name: Billionaires
bio: Just call him the Green Billionaire. With interests ranging from technology for cleaner power plants to harvested wood, Schmidheiny spends a good chunk of his time working on environmental issues. In 1992 he was a senior adviser to the Secretary General of the UN Earth Summit in Rio de Janeiro, and he's a frequent contributor of enviro-editorial pieces to major newspapers.  He's invested more than $200 million in sustainable development programs via his Avina Foundation since 1994, and plans to give more this year.  Schmidheiny inherited his nest egg from his father, the founder of the Holcim (formerly Holderbank) cement company.  His brother, Thomas, is chairman and majority shareholder of Holcim, but Stephan has never been involved with the company.  The bulk of his $3.1 billion fortune is invested in blue-chip U.S. equities. But at least half a billion is tied up in a museum-quality collection of modern art.

name: Billionaires
bio: Took over his father&#39s small screw wholesale business at age 19 and developed it from a two-man shop into a company with more than 32,000 employees and $4.5 billion in sales of industrial screws and fasteners. His secret: delivering the goods directly to the workers and mechanics who need them. Now retired from active business, he devotes his time to his 6,000-piece collection of 20th-century art featuring works of Picasso, Miró and Max Beckmann, housed in a museum within company headquarters and another brand new one in Schwaebisch Hall near Stuttgart.

name: Billionaires
bio: Russia's second-richest businessman, Roman Abramovich is nothing if not a survivor. He lost his parents as a child, dropped out of college and then accumulated his fortune in the 1990s through a series of inside deals in the Russian oil industry. But Russia's era of crony capitalism is drawing to a close. Abramovich recently transferred his business assets (including  stakes in oil giant Sibneft, Russian Aluminum and TV network ORT) to a British-registered holding company called Millhouse Capital and has dedicated himself to his work as governor of the Arctic region of Chukotka (inhabited by 79,000 Eskimos). Politically astute and commercially sensible as well.

name: Billionaires
bio: Great-granddad Warren started construction colossus Bechtel Group building railroads in 1890s Oklahoma Territory. Later: Hoover Dam, Oakland Bay Bridge. Dad Stephen Jr. took reins in 1960, built nuclear plants, Alaska pipeline, Chunnel. Riley now learning the ropes.

name: Billionaires
bio: His family-run construction giant built its reputation under founder Warren Bechtel by building Hoover Dam and Oakland Bay Bridge. Revenues declined last year to $14.3 billion.

name: Billionaires
bio: Inherited Seagram from father in 1971. Son Edgar Jr. shifted focus from beverages to entertainment. Sold to Vivendi for more than $30 billion. Edgar Sr. now serves on Vivendi Universal Board of Directors, sold additional $1.1 billion stake in Vivendi back to company last year; family remains firm's largest shareholder. Now focusing on philanthropy, Jewish heritage issues. Recipient of the Presidential Medal of Freedom as president of the World Jewish Congress, chairman of Hillel.

name: Billionaires
bio: Last year Ecclestone scored $1 billion from the sale of 25% of Formula One, his auto racing empire. It's unlikley he would have pocketed nearly as much in today's depressed advertising climate. Despite the "curse" of Formula One--both private investment firm Morgan Grenfell and pay-television giant Kirsch Group suffered financial woes after acquiring stakes--racing enjoyed a 4% increase in worldwide television viewers last year. Lagging American viewership is still a sore spot, but there are hopeful signs: Grand Prix in Indianapolis, airing only two weeks after Sept. 11, had better than expected ratings. Should his racing business ever hit the skids, Ecclestone boasts a billion-dollar family trust to fall back on.

name: Billionaires
bio: The Pittsburgh industrialist turned his father's coke and steel business into an investment and real estate powerhouse. He's an original backer of Silicon Valley venture capital gurus Kleiner Perkins and a donor to the Hillman Cancer Center at University of Pittsburgh.

name: Billionaires
bio: Critics didn't like the most recent chapter of his "Star Wars" saga, but fans went anyway: Proceeds from the "Phantom Menace" made the filmmaker an estimated $250 million last year alone. He'll get richer this year, when the next installment hits movie screens.

name: Billionaires
bio: Cofounded Home Depot with Arthur Blank after pair was dismissed from a now-defunct home improvement chain. Active philanthropist in Atlanta.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former Oracle salesman and ex-Larry Ellison protege; developed software for automating sales force. Left Oracle 1990, founded Siebel Systems 1993. Took public 1996.

name: Billionaires
bio: Dropped out of college to fly Navy fighters during World War II, then sold Cadillacs. Named company after his WWII carrier, U.S.S. Enterprise. His Enterprise rental car business took off in the 1970s. His son Andrew now oversees the company with $6.3 billion revenues in 2001.

name: Billionaires
bio: Sole owner of one of Germany's largest publishing groups, Hubert Burda Media Holding,which produces over 180 magazines throughout the world.   Titles at the $1 billion (revenues) company range widely from award-winning Focus business magazine to the tabloid Bunte. The group is one of the largest providers of German-content sites on the Internet. Businessman and philanthropist Burda keeps a high profile - attending such events as the recent World Economic Forum in New York. He founded the Hermann-Lenz Prize for German Literature and supports the Bambi Prize - the German  equivalent of the Academy Awards -  as well as a media center at Ben Gurion University in Israel.

name: Billionaires
bio: Honorary chairman of $24 billion (sales) Ito-Yokado retailing group, which includes 9,000 7-Eleven stores in Japan, 6,000 7-Eleven in U.S. and 182 Ito-Yokado supermarkets. Finally received approval last year to open the Ito-Yokado bank, a branchless consumer bank. Has since installed ATM's in 33% of its 7-Eleven outlets. It is the only bank in Japan that operates 24 hours a day, 365 days a year. Despite the overall faltering Japanese economy, the company managed to tread water, in part by reducing prices at Ito-Yokado stores.

name: Billionaires
bio: With younger brother Ronald, controls the cosmetics concern started by mother, Estee in 1946. Leonard was chief executive until 1999; now serves as chairman of the board. Today Estee Lauder Companies has 46% of the prestige cosmetics industry with such brands as Estee Lauder, Clinique, M.A.C., Aveda, Bobbi Brown and Stila.

name: Billionaires
bio: Successful banker and trained medical doctor sold most of his family's Banco Real to ABN Amro in 1998 for $2.1 billion. He heads Alfa Holdings, the remaining assets. Plus he owns hotels, a do-it-yourself home-repair chain that he's currently expanding, radio stations, soybean farms and a cattle ranch.

name: Billionaires
bio: Daughter of James L. (Bud) Walton (d. 1995), who pooled assets with brother Sam to start Wal-Mart. Daughters still own shares. Husband Stan develops real estate and owns shopping centers, often with Wal-Mart store as anchor. Couple became major sports magnates with purchase of NBA's Denver Nuggets and pro hockey's Colorado Avalanche, as well as minority stake in pro football's St. Louis Rams.

name: Billionaires
bio: Like sister Ann Kroenke, received heap of Wal-Mart shares from father, James L. (Bud) Walton.  Retail heiresses turned avid sports fans: nancy breeds racehorses on 350-acre Crown Center Farms.  With husband Bill, shares Kroenkes' interest in sports teams. Also owns pro hockey's St. Louis Blues.

name: Billionaires
bio: Mantegazza's escorted tour company, Globus & Cosmos, faced a rash of cancelations in the wake of last September's terrorist attacks in the U.S. Though cancelations normally carry stiff penalties, the company waived them temporarily. Bookings are still soft, but Chief Executive Mantegazza says overall sales were up by 8% in 2001. Sergio's father, Antonio, founded the company in 1928 with a bus he used to drive tourists around Lake Lugano. Today G&C chaperones 1.5 million tourists to more than 350 tour sites in 70 countries.  Most customers fly to their destinations on Monarch Airlines, G&C's own charter airline. Family control over G&C seems assured, as two of Sergio's sons, Paolo and Fabio (in charge of U.S. and U.K. operations, respectively) both hold senior management positions.

name: Billionaires
bio: One of the five founders of German software powerhouse SAP, trained physicist Tschira now runs his Heidelberg-based Klaus Tschira Foundation, which is dedicated to scientific and cultural projects that capture his imagination. Amateur astronomer Tschira has an asteroid named after him.

name: Billionaires
bio: Hands-on manager, Bauer heads the publishing business established by his grandfather in 1875. The business has been built on mass not class. Verlagsgruppe Bauer, with $1.4 billion (sales), puts out over 108 magazines worldwide: in Germany, it is a market leader in TV-listing magazines, women's magazines and magazines for young people. It also sells mass readership magazines like Maxi, the rather smutty Praline and holds the German licence for Playboy. In the U.S. the fare is similar: First for Women, Soap Opera Update, Soaps in Depth and Woman's World.

name: Billionaires
bio: Camera-shy media mogul runs Univision, the largest and most successful Spanish-language broadcaster in the U.S. Amid an increasingly competitive market, his new gamble is on a second Univision network, dubbed Telefutura, which launched in mid-January.

name: Billionaires
bio: No college, started as electronics salesman in dad's distribution company; borrowed $9,000, opened own stores, Sound of Music, 1966. Chain of low-cost superstores became Best Buy 1983, went public 1985. Overexpanded, nearly drowned in debt 1997. Consultant-led team helped get company back on track, now expecting $20 billion in sales for 2002. Now taking some Wall Street flacks for acquistion of Musicland stores, forays into Canada, but standing firm: "It took almost ten years before GE got credit. We think we're in a similar situation."

name: Billionaires
bio: Quarrel with father over family's small department store led Ohio State law school dropout to start The Limited in 1963 with $5,000 loan from aunt. Limited now $10.1 billion annual sales, more than 5,300 stores nationwide: Express, Structure, Lerner NY, Henri Bendel. Continues to spin off succesful brands: Abercrombie & Fitch 1998, Limited Too 1999; sold Lane Bryant 2001. Art enthusiast.

name: Billionaires
bio: Third son of oilman Perry Bass, but went his own way when father passed control of family fortune to brother Sid. Big investments in tax-friendly oil and gas royalty trusts. Unlike his brothers, Robert sold his Disney stake nearly a decade ago.

name: Billionaires
bio: The Bronfman family still retains a 5.5% stake in French media giant Vivendi, despite nephew Edgar Jr.'s resignation from the board in December. Charles uses his share to fund his philanthropies. Among these, Birthright Israel, a foundation that sponsors thousands of trips to Israel for Jewish young adults--28,000 so far. (Since Sept. 11 attendance is down at least 30%.) Recently bought house in Jerusalem; splitting his time between Israel and Montreal.

name: Billionaires
bio: Publicity-shy Gou (sometimes known as Kuo) did not hesitate to come out in defense of fellow billionaire Y.C. Wang, calling his counterpart's contribution to Taiwan greater than that of former president Lee Teng Hui. Gou has a 30% stake in computer component manufacturer Hon Hai Precison. Hon Hai recently brought a lawsuit against Tyco International for a patent violation.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman of Samsung Group. His flagship company Samsung Electronics, founded by his father in 1969, fared well in an otherwise tumultous 2001. While most of its competitors took losses this year, Samsung eked out a profit, mostly due to its sleek new cell phone designs and flat-screen televisions; stock increased nearly 70% over the year. Despite company successes, however, a more progressive Korean government is clamping down on leaders of this mighty chaebol: In December Lee was shamed by a conviction of mismanaging company funds and ordered to repay $5.5 million he used in 1988-92 to bribe then-President Roh Tae-woo. (The entire group of Samsung directors got slapped with an order to pay $74 million back to the conglomerate.) Management is appealing the decision. Outside of Samsung, Lee is an enthusiastic equestrian and a member of the International Olympic Committee; he handed U.S. champ Marion Jones the gold medal at the Sydney Olympics.

name: Billionaires
bio: Grandson of oil tycoon John D. Rockefeller. Ran Chase Manhattan bank, now concentrates on philanthropic endeavors.

name: Billionaires
bio: Took over his father's Dogus conglomerate after Ayhan Sahenk died of cancer at age 72 last year. Now lifts weights as part of regular exercise regimen.  The Dogus Holding's Garanti Bank is the nation's largest private bank, with assets of $15.5 billion. Trying to expand the struggling Tansas supermarket chain. Entered joint ventures with US media firms: Will produce Turkey's first cable-TV business channel with CNBC and publishing magazines in Turkey with National Geographic. The group includes the Ayhan Sahenk Foundation, in cooperation with the Turkish National Olympic Committee, to support an annual mountain biking race in his dad's honor.

name: Billionaires
bio: Litigious generic-drug czar almost made a bundle off last year's anthrax scare. Canada's health minister ordered Sherman's drug company, Apotex, to manufacture 1 million tabs of its generic anti anthrax drug. Bayer, which holds patent for Cipro, threatened to sue. The parties reached an out-of-court agreement--Bayer stores the generics, and Apotex won't charge the government for its pills unless they are used. Better news: Lilly's Prozac patent expired August; Apotex's generic version already boosting profits. Sherman also owns a 32% stake in Barr Laboratories, an American  specialty pharmaceutical company.

name: Billionaires
bio: Widow of Bronson Ingram, who inherited father's oil-and-barge business in 1963. Now billion-dollar Ingram Industries conglomerate in barges, books and insurance. Bronson died 1995, Martha inherited, sons now run divisions of the empire. Family also owns stake in computer-distributor Ingram Micro, taken public 1996. Martha active supporter of arts and culture in Nashville.

name: Billionaires
bio: Polish immigrant went from rags to riches in 1971 when she traded in her chambermaid uniform to become the third wife of Johnson & Johnson founder's son John Seward Johnson (d. 1983). After bitter inheritance dispute with Johnson's children from his first marriage, "Basia" emerged from the fracas with a large chunk of J&J stock and ownership of his palatial Princeton, N.J. estate Jasna Polana ("bright meadow" in Polish).

name: Billionaires
bio: With brother Leonard, controls the cosmetics concern started by mother, Estee, in 1946. Ronald a non-executive director. Today Estee Lauder Companies has 46% of the prestige cosmetics industry, with such brands as Estee Lauder, Clinique, M.A.C., Aveda, Bobbi Brown and Stila. Chairman of RSL Communications, which recently filed for bankruptcy.

name: Billionaires
bio: Sold debt-ridden McCaw Cellular to AT&T for $11.5 billion in 1993. Later founded (and funded) other wireless ventures including Nextel and satellite-based Teledesic. Now he's set his sights on the America's Cup by sponsoring the OneWorld Challenge racing syndicate.

name: Billionaires
bio: Rowling's main holding, Omni Hotels, continues expansion despite the sluggish economy, which hit lodging hard. Stockholder in Pacific Gas & Electric, ChevronTexaco and Bank of America. Former corporate lawyer joined father's Tana Oil & Gas business 1972, sold production units to Texaco 1989; 10 years later sold offshore exploration division to Unocal for $114 million. Donates to Christian youth organizations, drug rehab centers.

name: Billionaires
bio: He and James Goodnight met at N.C. State, teamed to develop statistical analysis program. SAS now world's largest privately held software maker with $1.2 billion in sales. Midway Airlines venture filed for bankruptcy last year; now back in the air.

name: Billionaires
bio: Stepped down as CEO of Holcim (formerly Holderbank) on Jan. 1.  He remains chairman of Holcim's board--and the company's majority shareholder--but in a curiously worded statement, declared that his decision took into account the "need for effective corporate governance."  There's talk that Schmidheiny may be positioning Holcim for a future without him as a majority shareholder, but the company dismisses these rumors.  If he were to leave the cement business behind, he could focus his attention on his two top-notch vineyards, Cuvaison in California and Chapel Hill in Australia.  Unlike his brother, Stephan (see), Thomas has worked in the family business his entire career.  But the two brothers do share an interest in the environment and sustainable development.

name: Billionaires
bio: Real estate empire makes his Hartz Mountain one of New Jersey's largest developers. Holdings include three Manhattan hotels and upscale office buildings in Jersey City and Weehawken, N.J. sporting Big Apple views. Sold the Village Voice and other publications in 1999; last year sold Hartz pet supply arm that launched Stern family fortunes.

name: Billionaires
bio: Lifelong cable guy now an entertainment titan: owns pro sports teams (basketball's New York Knicks, hockey's New York Rangers), cable channels (American Movie Classics, Bravo), movie theaters (Clearview Cinema Group), retailing (the Wiz), Radio City Music Hall. Struck out in attempt to gain control of the Boston Red Sox this winter.

name: Billionaires
bio: Cable veteran built Continental Cablevision into big operator, sold to US West in 1996; sold again 3 years later as MediaOne to AT&T for $58 billion. Took cash and shares, but cash faring better than sinking AT&T stock. Technically retired, but takes an active interest in ailing Ma Bell — cable unit slated to be sold to Comcast now staffed with Hostetter-trained executives.

name: Billionaires
bio: The son of legendary wildcatter H.L. Hunt lost ground when his $940 million bid for Calgary-based Berkely Petroleum was rejected, but did finally score a Canadian company with purchase of Chieftain International late last year. While Middle East politics continue to rattle his pipeline project in Yemen, Hunt Oil signed exclusive rights to drill in offshore area of Togo.

name: Billionaires
bio: Tulsa billionaire's timely bets in oil and banking paid off; his 75% stake in Oklahoma-based BOK Financial is up 50% for the year. Kaiser is a founder and supporter of the Tulsa Community Foundation.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman of one of Turkey's biggest and oldest conglomerates, Koc Holding, which just celebrated its 75th year. Wants company to become one of the world's 200 biggest companies. Koc is teaming up with Italy's Unicredito bank to create powerful financial-services brand in Turkey. In the auto sector Koc derives most of its money from exporting Fords and Fiats to other points in Europe. Revenues in first half of 2001 were $4.8 billion. Poor performance in auto, IT and retailing hurt Koc shares. Balanced those losses with healthier returns in real estate. Suffered public relations snafu in December when newspaper said Rahmi, age 71, was stepping down to make way for son and fellow board-member Mustafa. Koc issued press release denying the change in command.

name: Billionaires
bio: Fled Hungary for New York in 1958 at age 13. Studied economics at UCLA, became avid flier, met Louis Gonda. Along with Louis and his father Leslie Gonda, started International Lease Finance Corp with $150,000 and a $1.7-million bank loan. Bought in 1990 by insurance giant AIG for stock now worth billions. Steven still heads ILFC.

name: Billionaires
bio: The man behind Nintendo. The videogame maker is hoping new product launches will help it keep pace with fierce competition. Introduced its first portable game player in a decade, the GameBoy Advance in January 2001. Rolled out Nintendo GameCube in September 2001 to replace its Nintendo-64 player. Also the majority owner of the Seattle Mariners baseball team.

name: Billionaires
bio: Sulaiman bin Abdul Al Rajhi is the chairman and managing director of Al Rajhi Banking & Investment Corp., which operates under Islamic principles, paying no interest on deposits. One of four brothers, he owns the largest personal stake and plays the most active role in the banking empire. He also boasts the country's biggest poultry farm, a building-materials business and real estate. He reportedly has at least 23 children.

name: Billionaires
bio: Grandson of John Dorrance, the founder of Campbell Soup and the inventor of condensed soup. Continues to sit on his soup can inheritance and appears to do little else. To avoid U.S. taxes, he became an Irish citizen in 1994 under a controversial Irish passport-for-investment scheme. His siblings and fellow heirs to the fortune are still U.S. citizens.

name: Billionaires
bio: From his expatriate base in London, Foriel-Destezet is one of France's richest tax exiles. Chased abroad by a "wealth tax," Foriel-Destezet has reconfigured his investment portfolio to avoid French companies.  The bulk of his wealth is derived from his 19% stake in Adecco, the temporary services company he co-chairs with Swiss billionaire Klaus Jacobs. A board member of Vivendi Universal, he has investments in ISS, a Danish office cleaning firm, and Securitas, a Swedish security company. Securitas subsidiary Globe Aviation Services Corp. is currently under investigation by U.S. authorities. Globe Aviation provided the passenger screening in Boston's Logan Airport on Sept. 11. American Airlines Flight 11, which struck the World Trade Center's North Tower, departed from Logan.

name: Billionaires
bio: Mikhail Fridman founded Alfa Group in 1988 with a group of college friends. Made windfall profits on commodities trading, including a big oil-for-sugar deal with Cuba. Enlisted former foreign trade minister as partner. Outmaneuvered BP for control of one of Russia's largest oil fields in 1999 and now controls Tyumen Oil, Russia's third largest oil company. Recently he has been investing in mobile telecommunications (Vimpelcom) and television.

name: Billionaires
bio: Built his empire on the strengths of his contracting deals with the Saudi government. Expanded into banking and real estate before venturing into media, his true passion. Founded MBC (Middle East Broadcasting Center) and ART (Arab Radio & Television), the latter a chronic moneyloser and cash drain. Owns a majority of Dallah Albaraka, a conglomerate that runs vast Islamic banking operations, as well as real estate, construction and manufacturing interests. The ailing Islamic banking business is undergoing a massive overhaul. Like many wealthy Saudis, Kamel confronts allegations that some of his business interests may have been exploited by terrorist elements. Kamel denies any wrongdoing.

name: Billionaires
bio: With fellow UCLA engineer Henry Samueli, co-founded chip-maker Broadcom in 1991 to make chips for high-speed communications devices, cable modems. Company facing lean times, predicting a return to profitability this year. Partners first worked together at TRW 17 years ago, also worked together at PairGain. Nicholas, hard-driving CEO, has high public profile. Samueli heads tech side, also donates millions, mostly to education.

name: Billionaires
bio: Skoll, whose stake in Ebay was once worth $5 billion, has given millions to social causes in Silicon Valley through the Ebay Foundation and Skoll Community Fund. The online flea market continues to outperform expectations, drawing 4 million unique visitors a day during the holiday season. The company is heading abroad, having acquired other auction sites like Italy's iBazar and a stake in South America's Mercadolibre.com. Up next: a joint project with Sony to develop a TV show based on the stories behind rare collectibles featured on the site. Stay tuned.

name: Billionaires
bio: Hollywood legend made his name with hits like Jaws, E.T. and Raiders of the Lost Ark. The founding partner in Dreamworks SKG studio also a passionate archivist of Holocaust survivors' accounts.

name: Billionaires
bio: Runs $6 billion (assets) global commodities empire inherited from late father Aditya Birla. Is the world’s largest producer of viscose staple fiber and the biggest aluminum manufacturer in India. With recent acquisition of a 10% stake in Larsen & Toubro, an engineering and cement company from fellow billionaire Dhirubhai Ambani, emerged as one of the country’s top cementmakers. A homebody, he is known never to miss important functions at his children’s schools.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of oil tycoon J. Paul Getty, but left family business to study music, write operas. Benefactor of L.A. Opera and L.A. Philharmonic. But still makes time for business; major stakeholder in San Francisco-based mutual fund group Forward Funds.

name: Billionaires
bio: Kristiansen's family-owned Lego toy company is bouncing back after losing $121 million in 2000.  Sales have grown an estimated 5% last year, with preschool toys leading the charge.  Beyond Lego, Kristiansen invests in new technologies via his Kirkbi A/S holding company.  Unlike the solid, evergreen appeal of Lego, this portfolio invests in riskier technology startups like Freepen, maker of wireless computer mice shaped like traditional pens.

name: Billionaires
bio: Launched Polo in 1967 with $50,000, transformed men's clothing line into brand behemoth; now sells clothes for men, women and children, as well as fragrances, linens, paint and accessories. Collects antique cars and motorcycles; owns homes in New York, Colorado and Jamaica.

name: Billionaires
bio: After fighting in Israel's War of Independence, the Holocaust survivor moved to Sydney, where he opened a deli in 1956. Now known as Australia's  shopping mall king. Through his Westfield Holdings Lowy owned the lease for the World Trade Center's subterranean shopping plaza. Lost an employee in the disaster. In January Westfield shelled out $2.3 billion for a stake in Rodamco North America, making Lowy the third-largest mall owner in the U.S. Still makes time for a regular game of tennis.

name: Billionaires
bio: The junk-bond financier's portfolio has been bolstered by his stake in Golden State Bankcorp, but he's still struggling to turn around wounded cosmetics giant Revlon. Cigar-chomping LBO-er made killing selling New World Communications to Rupert Murdoch in 1996.

name: Billionaires
bio: Cofounded chipmaker Broadcom with fellow UCLA engineer Henry Nicholas; Samueli heads tech side, also donates millions, mostly to education. Company predicting sluggish sales will improve.

name: Billionaires
bio: With the financial backing of the Haniel and Schmidt-Ruthenbeck families, Otto Beisheim was able to rapidly expand the company he founded in 1964. Today Metro AG is one of the world's largest retail groups (supermarkets, department stores, do-it-yourself and consumer electronics stores) with over $41 billion in annual sales. He owns 18.84% of the company, as do the Haniel and Schmidt-Ruthenbeck families. Although officially retired from Metro, Beisheim, a German-born Swiss citizen, is actively involved in an internet and technology company called Beisheim Holding Schweiz AG.

name: Billionaires
bio: Saw his 37% interest in property developer New World Development decline some 30% in value since last year. Has a stake in Stanley Ho's casino group, which for 40 years had a monopoly on Macau gambling. In February the group was forced to share the industry with two other outfits, all recently rewarded licenses.

name: Billionaires
bio: One-time right-hand man in business to Italy’s prime minister, Silvio Berlusconi. Chief executive of Mediolanum SpA, Italian life insurance and fund management company that’s part of Berlusconi’s empire. Entertaining the possibility of buying Berlusconi’s 36% stake to help the politician resolve conflicts of interest. Problem is, he doesn’t have enough money. Enjoys mountain biking.

name: Billionaires
bio: Martin Ebner's two trademarks are bow ties and an aggressive brand of shareholder advocacy.  Since founding his own investment vehicle, BZ Group Holding, in 1988, Ebner has frequently put his money to work in companies he believes could be better managed.  His current pet project is Sweden's Investor, whose shares trade at nearly a 30% discount. Ebner also holds large stakes in Nestle, ABB, the Credit Suisse Group, UBS, Bayer, Eli Lilly and Aventis. In January he doubled his 10% stake in Swiss insurer Baloise.

name: Billionaires
bio: International Data Group rode the tech wave with instructional books ("Internet for Dummies"), magazines ("Industry Standard") and conferences (Macworld).

name: Billionaires
bio: The oldest of eight children, he built barns to pay college tuition.  Opened his first home improvement store in 1972. Now Menard's Inc. trying to fend off rapidly expanding competitors Home Depot, Lowe's.

name: Billionaires
bio: Romanian-born brothers run a shipping, real estate, energy and banking conglomerate. Monaco-based Sammy oversees shipping assets, including the family's stake in Royal Caribbean.(Sammy's son Eyal sits on Royal Caribbean's board.) The leisure cruise line is currently duking it out with  with Carnival Corp. for control of P&O Princess Cruises. Yuli manages the Israeli operations from Tel Aviv. Watch for the brothers to buy Israel's stake in Zim Navigation, a shipping container company. Last year Sammy shelled out $5.3 million for a Gerhard Richter to add to his vast contemporary art collection.

name: Billionaires
bio: The richest man in British Columbia built his fortune slowly, cobbling together an empire from supermarkets, billboards, car dealerships and even oddball tourist meccas like Ripley's "Believe It or Not" and Louis Tussaud's wax museums. Last year acquired some radio stations and opened three new Hyundai dealerships. Owns Frank Sinatra's old digs in Palm Springs.

name: Billionaires
bio: These  brothers have guarded their privacy so well that next to nothing is known about them, except that they benefit from a visionary investment in giant retailer Metro. They own 18.84%, as do Otto Beisheim and the Haniel families.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former car salesman turned $3 PC sale ad in Chicago Tribune into billion-dollar technology products and services firm.  Sales are up despite IT scare. Stepped down as chairman and chief executive past January, now presides as chairman emeritus. Sits on the boards of Northwestern (Kellogg School of Management) and the Anti-Defamation League.

name: Billionaires
bio: After two years of watching the stock slide and sniping at management, John Malone is free of AT&T again. Media investment company Liberty Media spun off in August. Malone planning invasion of Europe, starting with June purchase of cable systems from Deutsche Telekom. Yale grad became right-hand man of TCI founder Bob Magness (d. 1996), after his death engineered sale to AT&T, which still has the cable systems but may soon sell them at a discount to Comcast.

name: Billionaires
bio: Minnesota farm boy worked his way through college printing wedding-invitations. In 1975 convinced retiring owner to sell company for $2 million, paid over ten years. Stepped down from chief executive position at his printing company Taylor Corp. last fall to concentrate on NBA's Timberwolves and farm holdings.

name: Billionaires
bio: The World War II veteran sold Slim-Fast, a nutritional supplement company, to Unilever for $2.3 billion in 2000. Ardent Democrat contributed to Hillary Rodham Clinton's New York senatorial campaign.

name: Billionaires
bio: As chief executive of Mashreqbank, Al Ghurair is an advocate of  anti-money laundering laws and is an important figure in dealing with that issue in the Middle East. Also owns shopping malls and a cement company.

name: Billionaires
bio: Head of media-centric investment bank Allen & Co. prefers to stay out of the limelight, but his annual media mogul powwow in Sun Valley keeps his profile high. Last year's bash was no exception: News Corp. and Disney clinched their deal for the Fox Family channel, but festivities turned somber after death of conference attendee Katharine Graham.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman of Sankyo, a major manufacturer of Pachinko (slot) machines. Sold 6% more machines last year despite a weak economy. Company's stake in Asahi bank dragged down results.

name: Billionaires
bio: A third-generation grocer based in San Antonio, Butt continues to expand his H-E-B grocery chain. Runs 285 stores in Texas, Louisiana and Mexico. Grandmother opened first grocery store in 1905 to "keep the family afloat." Butt started bagging groceries at age 8. Now bags approximately $9 billion in sales. Company donates 5% of pretax profits to charity.

name: Billionaires
bio: Earl Cadogan and his three children own the second-most-expensive swath of real estate in the U.K. The 90 acres in the upscale Chelsea district of London have been in the Earl's family for almost 250 years. Run by professional managers, the estate has almost doubled its value in the past 4 years.

name: Billionaires
bio: Only son of Hallmark founder Joyce C. Hall and onetime company head is now retired. Company remains firmly in family's control. Joyce's grandson, Donald J. Hall, Jr. took over chief executive position of greeting card giant at start of 2002.

name: Billionaires
bio: Here's a neat way to make a fortune. Lead a buyout of Mexico's best bank, Banamex, in a deal with government of now-discredited president Carlos Salinas in 1992. When the bank collapses a few years later, along with Mexico's economy, accept $4.5 billion in taxpayer-funded bailouts. When Mexico really starts to look rosy in 2001, sell it to the largest U.S. bank, Citigroup, for $12.5 billion in cash and stock.  That's just what Hernandez did, taking a $1.9 billion cut. He now sits on Citigroup's board and is chairman of Banamex.

name: Billionaires
bio: USC graduate started storage business in 1972, merged with Storage Equities and went public in 1995. Hughes, a former real estate executive, owns 31% of what became nation's largest self storage company. Thoroughbred enthusiast, owns over 100 active race horses. Since the death of his son, became cancer treatment advocate: funds research and patient care. In 2000, he created Minnesota's Parker Hughes Cancer Center with a $200 million endowment.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman of world's largest car retailer, Auto Nation, sells cars using fixed, "no-haggle" prices. Cashed out most of stock last fall. The college dropout also owns football's Miami Dolphins.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founder and honorary chairman of Promise, Japan's third-largest consumer finance company. Downturn presenting buying opportunities: Last year Jinnai scooped up two of his competitors. Third son of a farmer who had seven children; once worked at the Ministry of Agriculture.
