Owns 595 hectares of farm in Hokkaido: "Japan's agriculture is in decline, and I would like to use my experience as an entrepreneur to find new ways to revitalize the industry." Last summer he constructed the biggest "vegetable factory" in Japan. The factory is controlled by computers and produces organic vegetables.

name: Billionaires
bio: Half-brothers Charles and Rupert Johnson run mutual fund giant Franklin Resources. Yale-grad Charles is CEO; ex-Marine Rupert is vice chairman. Last April purchased Fiduciary Trust, only to watch it become one of the hardest-hit firms in the World Trade Center attacks. Franklin manages $246 million in assets for 8.4 million clients.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of Korean chip maker H. S. Kim, whose Anam company had American-educated James start up U.S. marketing arm in 1968. U.S. company now does $2 billion annual sales: during Asian financial crisis, bailed out dad's company back in Korea. Chip market now weaker, losses and layoffs piling up. Also owns large stake in Electronics Boutique, retailer started by wife Agnes as a mall stand in King of Prussia, Pa.

name: Billionaires
bio: A former deputy prime minister, Vladimir Potanin took over the assets (but not the debts) of two Soviet-era foreign trade banks in the early nineties. Bought control of metals giant Norilsk Nickel and oil company Sidanko in lopsided privatization auctions in 1995.Invested with George Soros in telecommunications holding company, Svyazinvest, in 1997, though the two investors have since had a falling out. Potanin remains a power in banking and metals, though he has sold off most of his oil interests. Recently he began investing in pig farms and grain trading.

name: Billionaires
bio: A trained butcher from Swabia, Anton Schlecker started off selling meat products. Spotting a market opportunity in 1974, when price controls were relaxed, he diversified and started offering drugstore items at rock-bottom prices. His first American-style drugstore opened in 1975. He now has more than 11,000 outlets throughout Germany and Europe and over 70% share of the German market.  Success trick? Low prices and service to even seemingly unprofitable locations, such as towns with small populations. His $4.5 billion (sales) Schlecker drugstores are as ubiquitous and as well-known as Walgreens is in the U.S.

name: Billionaires
bio: Along with sister Charmaine, Bruno Schroder owns almost half of his family's financial services company, Schroders Plc. A fourth-generation banker, Schroder continues as the non executive director. Continuing the firm's expansion in alternative investments, Schroder paid $48 million in October for London-based Beaumont Capital Management, a hedge fund with $275 million under management. Schroder's stock down 35% from last year, shaving almost $1 billion from the family's net worth. Known as an amiable man who loves flying airplanes, hunting stags, as well as relaxing at his Scottish estate.

name: Billionaires
bio: "The Donald" is still making deals: in the midst of buying Manhattan's Delmonico Hotel for $115 million, looking to expand exclusive Palm Beach, Fla. country club. Plan to build world's tallest building in Chicago scaled back after Sept. 11 attacks to a mere 78 stories. The attacks scrapped a deal to buy Conseco's half of the GM Building in New York. Now Trump is suing Conseco.

name: Billionaires
bio: Started buying ailing Sunbelt real estate in the 1970s with frat brother Robert Lurie (d. 1990), now his Equity Office Properties is the largest office-space holder in America after the U.S. government. Less successful investment in American Classic Voyages; cruise ship operator entered bankruptcy in October.

name: Billionaires
bio: Bouygues--pronounced "Bweeg"--is chairman and CEO of the Bouygues Group, a diversified (telecom, media, construction) conglomerate founded by his father in 1952. He&#39s still fuming over France’s recent 3G mobile telephone license auction, which he calls a "disaster."  Last year Bouygues pulled his telecom unit out of the bidding, letting France Telecom and Vivendi Universal plunk down billions of euros for two of four available licenses. His caution was justified. With a full-fledged 3G network still years away, the two new license holders are now scrambling to justify their investments. Meanwhile, the French government appears to be responding to some of Bouygues&#39 complaints: In October  Paris revised the bidding process for the remaining two licenses.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founded the JCDecaux outdoor advertising company in 1964. His sons now run the publicly traded company as co-chief executives, while Jean-Claude sits on the board. With sales expected to top $1 billion in 2001, JCDecaux is the leading billboard company in Europe. But the firm is expanding its U.S. presence, too. In January JC Decaux and its partner, Viacom Outdoor Advertising, signed a lucrative 20-year contract with the city of Los Angeles to provide bus shelters, public toilets and information kiosks. The deal is expected to generate more than $800 million in advertising revenues, making it the richest "street furniture" deal in U.S. history.

name: Billionaires
bio: Richard DeVos and Jay Van Andel were partners, friends in high school and became sales reps for Nutrilite in 1948, then left to start own soap-selling business. Became Amway, with 3 million reps selling $5 billion worth of products worldwide. DeVos retired 1993, Van Andel in 1995, second generation still in charge. Company reorganized as Alticor, including Internet arm Quixtar.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founded and still runs Ferrero Chocolates. A man obsessed, he has said he can only speak one word—“chocolate.” One sign of change: He has started to bring in outside managers to help him run his intensely private confectionary group, which is among Europe’s top five. Avid churchgoer.

name: Billionaires
bio: Onetime attornmey built Kendall-Jackson into very profitable populist wine concern. Courted, then spurned, beverage conglomerate suitors, now concentrating on high-end, low-volume vineyards.

name: Billionaires
bio: His Quanta Computer unseated Japan's Toshiba Corp. as the world's largest notebook manufacturer last year. It produces one out of every seven notebook computers sold worldwide. He expects to triple sales to $10 billion by 2005. Investors are also taking note. Quanta's stock price gained 30% since last year, adding half a billion dollars to his net worth.

name: Billionaires
bio: A granddaughter of Campbell Soup founder John T. Dorrance, who invented  process to produce condensed canned soup. She is an active horse breeder.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former Campbell Soup accountant became general manager of gourmet pet food maker Iams in 1970. Bought company  12 years later, focused on high-end breeder business, expanded to $600 million annual sales. Sold pet food giant to Procter & Gamble in 1999 for $2.3 billion.  Now concentrates on running Mathile Family Foundation: pledged $100 million endowment for Dayton-area philanthropy.

name: Billionaires
bio: Formed McCain Foods, a multinational food empire, with brother Harrison in 1957. The brothers prospered selling frozen french fries and pizzas.  Brotherly love turned sour in early 1990s when Harrison rallied other family members against Wallace's plan to install his son Michael as successor. The dispute went into arbitration, with Harrison emerging victorious and Wallace unemployed. Wallace and his son retreated to Toronto where they bought a 33% stake in pork producer Maple Leaf Foods. Estranged from his brother, Wallace still retains a one-third stake in McCain Foods.

name: Billionaires
bio: What began in 1899 as a family business peddling butter, bacon and eggs from a market stall has evolved into a supermarket kingdom with 110 stores and 81 gas stations across the U.K. Sir Ken took over the family business in 1951 and turned William Morrison Supermarkets into the U.K.'s sixth-largest chain. Morrison, who owns an estimated 39% of the company, has tapped managing director John Dowd as his likely successor, though when he'll step down is anyone's guess.

name: Billionaires
bio: Shrewd banker with deft diplomatic skills. In 1982, acquired Dao Heng Bank, then a small, obscure bank in Hong Kong, and turned it into a modern and successful banking operation before selling it for $2.9 billion in profits last year. In the 1990s Quek entered the Malaysian financial-services market with Hong Leong Bank. Today Hong Leong Bank is one of ten anchor banks in Malaysia, with $8.2 billion in deposits and annual profits of more than $134 million. He was educated in the U.K. and is a barrister by training. Cousin Kwek Leng Beng based in Singapore oversees the family's property and hotel businesses.

name: Billionaires
bio: A former money manager for the Bass family, Rainwater struck out on his own in 1986. Investments in oil and gas paid off big last year, but this year his stake in insurance company Gainsco is suffering.

name: Billionaires
bio: Egyptian-born Saban snared the biggest cash payout in Hollywood last year--$1.5 billion--with the sale to Disney of his share of cable channel Fox Family Worldwide. A self-described "cartoon schlepper," his biggest hit was the live-action Japanese import Mighty Morphin Power Rangers. Now he's looking for ways to invest his take, starting with the music business and talent agencies. Watch for a media acquisition in Israel, too.

name: Billionaires
bio: The North Carolina native made his fortune in banking, first by helping his father restore struggling Bank of North Carolina. Merged with NCNB in 1982, renamed NationsBank; later merged with BankAmerica to form Bank of America.

name: Billionaires
bio: The owner of bankrupt Philippine Airlines is struggling to keep the business afloat.  Last year he managed to pay down 10% of the airlines’ $2 billion in debt, and the company even turned a profit for the second year in  a row.  Now he’s duking it out with old pal John Gokongwei’s Cebu Pacific Airlines for lucrative Korean routes.  Tan’s fortune originated as a tobacco business.  He also owns a significant stake in Philippine National Bank.

name: Billionaires
bio: Fashion icon had a busy year. Donated $160 million to Afghan refugees through his Afghan Emergency initiative. Acquired the last part of Italian clothing manufacturer Simint that he didn’t already own. Launched a line of perfume, opened stores in Buenos Aires and Moscow and expanded in New York. Despite the crisis, the business, which he owns 100% of, still delivered strong results: sales were up 23% to $1.1 billion last year. Last Summer, survived a fire in his palazzo in Milan in which he was trapped on the top floor. A loner, Armani is helped in business by sister Rosanna, while niece Roberta deals with celebrities and is considered his likely successor.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founded Home Depot in 1978 with partner Bernard Marcus after being fired by now-defunct hardware chain. Blank stepped down from his chief executive post and resigned from board last year. Now focusing on promoting the arts in Georgia.

name: Billionaires
bio: As a competent and honest industrial tycoon, Vladimir Bogdanov stands out in Russia. He has run Surgutneftegaz, the country's fourth-largest oil company, since the Soviet era, investing steadily in his business, raising productivity and accumulating $3.6 billion in spare cash. An unpretentious and reclusive man, Bogdanov is regarded as something of an eccentric. He prefers his Siberian factory town to Moscow, walks to work and even does his own grocery shopping.

name: Billionaires
bio: Desmarais bought his father's one-route Ontario bus company for a buck in 1951, parlaying it into Power Corp., a $10 billion (sales) transportation, insurance and communications titan. Last summer, in a $25 billion deal, Power Corp. acquired a 25% stake in media giant Bertelsmann AG. Profits, which for the past decade have grown at least 15% annually, have stalled at 3% for the first three quarters of 2001. Desmarais also owns Investors Group, Canada's largest group of mutual funds. While sons Andre and Paul Jr. run Power Corp., Paul Sr. collects Canadian art and bird hunts on his private estate in Quebec.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founded software maker PeopleSoft in 1987 with $2 million nest egg. Took public in 1992; had $1.3 billion in sales by 1998. Introduced one of the first programs for automating personnel work, then offered financial, inventory planning and purchasing software. Reduced role in company following 1999 stock slump.

name: Billionaires
bio: The last of Japan's electronics tycoons. Third of four sons of a sewing machine wholesaler in Kobe, he never got further than high school. Today his Funai Electronics is the world's largest maker of VCRs. Labor problems in Japan forced Funai Electric to venture into China in the early 1990s, at a time when Japan's major electronics firms stayed put. Thanks to its cheap Chinese base, profitable Funai is outperforming its competition. Expanded its partnership with Dutch-based Royal Philips Electronics, agreeing to produce VCRs under the Philips brand. Will open a new factory in Thailand in March.

name: Billionaires
bio: Started Paychex payroll business with $3,000 in 1971; now handles the books for over 350,000 clients. 1983 IPO gave millionaire status to each of the firm's 19 original partners. Ran for New York governor under Independence Party banner in 1994 and 1998.

name: Billionaires
bio: Billion dollar beneficiary of Citigroup's buyout of Banamex, Harp now spends much of his time tending to his nation's poor. Through Banamex Social Foundation, he oversees development aid to the impoverished of south Mexican state of Oaxaca. He also remains the chairman of the board of Banamex's holding company.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of legendary tycoon Li Ka-shing. Earned his mark as a stand-alone magnate when he convinced Rupert Murdoch to pay $950 million for Star TV in 1995. His Internet concern Pacific Century CyberWorks' high stock price in 2000 facilitated the purchase of Cable & Wireless HKT, a giant telecom provider that controls 90% of Hong Kong's fixed phone lines. Unfortunately, purchase also saddled the company with more than $4.7 billion in debt. To stay ahead of the creditors, Richard Li keeps issuing more debt. Earlier this year he offered $450 million worth of convertible bonds. In February of last year he issued $750 million worth of convertible bonds to a business partner. Charming and talented dealmaker. Grew up in Hong Kong. Attended Stanford University but dropped out. Did stint with Canadian investment banking firm Gordon Capital before moving back to Hong Kong to work for father's company. Now on his own.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman of Mexico's number two television network, TV Azteca, Salinas has recently been casting an eye stateside. He created Azteca America network last fall. Effort off to a slow start, however, as network still reaches only 28% of U.S. Latino households. On bright side, crown jewel TV Azteca is gaining market share against rival Televisa at home. Salinas also owns stake in Mexican electronics retail chain, Grupo Elektra, which is facing mounting competition from discounters. Hobbies include golf and reading nonfiction, most recently on the subject of eighteenth-century Mexico.

name: Billionaires
bio: After two failed attempts at starting businesses, founded Keyence, a factory automation equipment manufacturer. Today the company, with sales of $630 million, is a leader in optical and magnetic sensors.

name: Billionaires
bio: Saved Morrison Knudsen from bankruptcy 1996. Now newly named Washington Group is coming out of its own bankruptcy filing after botched acquisition of Raytheon's engineering and construction unit. Other assets still running strong: railroads, mines.

name: Billionaires
bio: Ethiopian-born and raised in Saudi Arabia, Al Amoudi made his fortune in construction and real estate before branching out to buy oil refineries in Sweden and Morocco. The largest foreign investor in both Sweden and his native Ethiopia, he is currently expanding his African investments through the AIG Africa Infrastructure Fund.

name: Billionaires
bio: Don Alberto's old-time fortune stretches from insurance and retail to mining, chemicals and huge cattle spreads. His Industrias Penoles is the world's largest producer of refined silver.

name: Billionaires
bio: Troubled times for the Bass family. Sold $1.8 billion of Disney stock for margin call in late September; other telecom and high-tech investments have plunged. Father Perry built the family empire from oil fortune made by uncle Sid Richardson. Tapped eldest son Sid to handle the money in 1968. Brother Robert broke from the family's business soon after. Smart move - sold out his Disney stake years ago, and made lucrative investments in oil and gas. Lee and Ed kept their money with Sid, though Ed reportedly wasn't involved in the September sale.

name: Billionaires
bio: Amazon.com chief made good on his prediction: Company posted its first profit in the fourth quarter of 2001, boosting the stock as investors returned. Princeton physics grad realized sales potential of books on Internet while rising star at hedge fund D.E. Shaw. Borrowed money from parents and moved to Seattle: recent expansions have gone well beyond books into toys, electronics, Drugstore.com, but core book-and-music business is, so far, only profit generator.

name: Billionaires
bio: The secretive and committed Buddhist reportedly is a citizen of the small Pacific kingdom of Tonga. He remains, however, a shrewd Hong Kong real estate investor. Chen delisted his flagship Nan Fung Textiles back in 1989 and rode the Hong Kong real estate boom. Apparently unscathed by the 1997 Asian crisis, he bought more than 12% of developer Sino Land owned by fellow billionaire Ng Teng Fong at a bargain. So far his investment has made him $17 million in dividends.

name: Billionaires
bio: Grandfather John T. Dorrance invented soup condensation process for family's Campbell Soup firm. Bennett is Arizona real estate developer, collects antique cars.

name: Billionaires
bio: With husband Donald, opened the first Gap store in 1969 in San Francisco, added or acquired brands including BabyGap, Old Navy, Banana Republic. The chain is grappling with growth pains and falling profits: The Fisher family is no longer in day-to-day control after departure of sons William and Robert from executive ranks, but Donald remains chairman and Doris remains a member of the board of directors.

name: Billionaires
bio: Medical doctor founded Hospital Corp. of America with father and Kentucky Fried Chicken's Jack Massey. Merged with Columbia Healthcare 1994. The former Air Force flight surgeon was instrumental in guiding company through Medicare billing-fraud investigation that cost company $745 million in fines. Expanded firm overseas, now owns hospitals in England and Switzerland.

name: Billionaires
bio: Immigrated to the U.S. from Nazareth, Israel at age 5. Father ran grocery stores outside Flint, Mich. After Michigan State, invested alongside older brother Alec in small tech firms; parted ways 1995. Now runs Platinum Equity, Los Angeles-based buyout firm. Thirty deals since 1995, all using lots of leverage.

name: Billionaires
bio: Father, James C. Kellogg III, became a partner at Spear, Leeds and Kellogg in 1945; became nation's largest specialist firm on the New York and American stock exchanges. Eventually took control of the firm, passed reins to son in 1973. Sold fall 2000 to Goldman Sachs for $6.5 billion.

name: Billionaires
bio: Third-generation head of family business founded by John Michael Kohler 1873. Started with iron and steel foundry, moved into plumbing business. Now includes faucets, household accessories, generators; company also owns luxury hotel, 2 golf courses. Ownership once spread among 300 shareholders; Herb led drive to consolidate family holdings 1998.

name: Billionaires
bio: Family's vast holdings extend from paper to power. Still, looking somewhat stagnant this year as its crown holding, pulp manufacturer CMPC, goes nowhere fast due to depressed paper prices.

name: Billionaires
bio: Texas wildcatter agreed to sell Mitchell Energy & Development last August to Devon Energy for $3.5 billion. Mitchell's take: some $730 million and 9% of Devon. Got start at Amoco in 1940. Army stint; founded own oil exploration company in 1946. Struck it rich with massive gas fields in northern Texas. Aided hometown of Galveston with historic preservation, new hotels, offices and Mardi Gras festival.

name: Billionaires
bio: Bear market hit Cisco Systems hard. The world's largest networking-products maker overestimated demand for its wares. Frugal Morgridge became president and CEO in 1988 and pushed sales up 300-fold. He now serves as chairman.

name: Billionaires
bio: Dallas-based investor owns interests in businesses ranging from chemicals and waste management to titanium metals and steel-rod manufacturing.  Former bank examiner made a name for himself in 1980s' hostile takeovers, greenmail. Recently backed a group of investors who sought, but failed, to take control of Wisconsin-based industrial-equipment maker Gehl. Simmons built up drugstore chain with purchase of Dallas store in 1961 for $5,000; sold to Eckerd Corp. for $50 million in 1973.

name: Billionaires
bio: In what may be the world record for biggest fortune lost, Softbank's son dropped $77 billion in two years, as the value of his holdings fell 98%. Reasons: bursting of Internet bubble, questionable investment in bankrupt Nippon Credit Bank (now Aozora Bank) and delays in broadband deployment. After racking up $3 billion in debt, Softbank is now selling assets.

name: Billionaires
bio: The biggest developer and operator of malls in the Philippines. Sy's malls are cash cows generating some $60 million a year in profits. The 77-year-old Sy may look his age but is still as ambitious as ever. He has plans to open two new malls in the Philippines and to expand into China in the next two years. He is also planning to list his banking operation Banco de Oro on the Philippines stock exchange this year.

name: Billionaires
bio: As boss of Lukoil, Russia's largest oil company, Alekperov used his close friendship with the fuel and energy minister to muscle into lucrative oil deals around the Caspian Sea in the early 1990s. He has been expanding downstream, buying refineries in Eastern Europe, building a fleet of tankers and snapping up the Getty gas station chain in the U.S. In an apparent political vendetta, Lukoil recently used its position as minority shareholder in TV network TV6 to bankrupt the network and push old rival and former oligarch Boris Berezovsky out of the television network.

name: Billionaires
bio: The juggler. Owns or has stakes in 210 companies, all under the Virgin umbrella. Some of his more recent ventures: Virgin Wine, Virgin Cars and Virgin Active, a chain of South African and British health clubs. To raise money for his biggest new venture these days, Virgin Mobile, Branson has been selling off smaller pieces of his empire, including 18 Virgin retail stores in France and his stake in Virgin One, the mortgage lender. Virgin Atlantic, his best-known brand, has reduced its number of flights by 15% after the Sept. 11 attacks and posted a small loss in the latest quarter. Added some new flights in February, saying leisure business was looking up. Never one to miss a marketing op, Branson hosted a joint press conference with then New York City Mayor Rudolph Giuliani in early November to boost tourism. He flew 450 Brits to the event, including firefighters, outfitting them in “I Love New York” T shirts.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former grocery bagboy lost gamble on floundering Kmart, though he claims he collared his shares. But he did sell his short-held stake in Fleming, Kmart's food distributor, for a profit. Made his money buying supermarkets; recent e-commerce ventures largely fizzled.

name: Billionaires
bio: Broadcast.com cofounder sold out to Yahoo, hedged fortune with derivatives. Now overly passionate owner of pro basketball's Dallas Mavericks.

name: Billionaires
bio: As vice chairman and the largest single shareholder in security firm Securitas AB, Douglas has been the biggest beneficiary of the company's  growing dominance of the global security market. The $5.8 billion (sales) company has become the number one security guard service, in part by acquiring such American stalwarts as Burns and Pinkerton. Securitas saw demand for its guard services spike in the U.S. following the Sept. 11 attacks.

name: Billionaires
bio: George Soros' former No. 2 man, placed the billion-dollar bet against the British pound in 1992, generated 30 percent returns for Soros' Quantum Fund. Caught tech bandwaggon at last stop, got hammered for $3 billion in early 2000 and resigned. Still in charge of $3 billion Duquesne Capital hedge fund, founded in 1981.

name: Billionaires
bio: Daughter of tireless salesman Curtis Carlson (d. 1999), who invested $50 to start Gold Bond Trading Stamps in 1938, built into marketing, travel, hospitality conglomerate that includes Radisson Hotels, T.G.I. Friday's. Sister Marilyn placed in charge of company in 1998. Sizable Carlson Companies travel segment struggling along with rest of industry after September terrorist attacks.

name: Billionaires
bio: Call him Stelios, please. Best known in Europe for his EasyJet discount airline (modeled on Herb Kelleher's Southwest Airlines). Despite a significant drop-off in ticket sales after Sept. 11, EasyJet reported 2001 revenues of $510 million, an increase of more than 20%. EasyJet responded to the slump by slashing fares and halting service to airports that couldn't guarantee that every bag loaded on an EasyJet plane would be inspected. Stelios, 35, remains a serial entrepreneur, pushing ahead with plans to launch an online bank and expand his Easy brand Internet cafe chain and rental car company.  Last March Stelios took his Stelmar shipping company public on the NYSE, in one of the most successful offerings of the year.

name: Billionaires
bio: One of the  founders of German software giant SAP. Mathematician Hector now devotes his time to managing the H.W.& J. Hector Stiftung, his cultural and philanthropic foundation established to support cancer and AIDs reseach, art and historical preservation.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founder of ultra-stylish sunglasses-and-accessory maker Oakley. Started with motorcycle goggles in 1975, started sunglasses in 1984. Avoided advertising, but got free publicity from athletes wearing Oakley shades. Now also makes watches, shoes, apparel. Publicity-shy Jannard tried to withdraw from day-to-day management in mid-1990s, but came back as CEO in 1999 after stock dived; stock tripled after his return. Stock nose-dived again last fall after tiff with largest distributor, Sunglass Hut; rebounded after dispute resolved in December, but fourth-quarter profit still off 66%.

name: Billionaires
bio: With half brother Charles Johnson, runs Franklin Resources, one of the 10 largest money managers in the U.S.

name: Billionaires
bio: Assistant store manager turned CEO led the expansion of discount retailer Kohl's from family-owned Wisconsin department store to a national chain, with 382 stores in 28 states. Led management buyout in 1986, took public in 1992. Stepped down as CEO in 1999, remains chairman until term ends 2002.

name: Billionaires
bio: Mittal heads Ispat International, the world's fourth-largest steel group, with annual sales of $5 billion. Ispat's stock has recovered from a November low, but is still down more than 50% from last year. Good thing newly acquired steel plants in Kazakhstan and Algeria are doing well. Now Mittal is betting he can turnaround Romania's state-run loser, which he acquired in July. On the home front, Mittal is mired in political scandal. Made big-time donations to Tony Blair's party while ailing competitor and possible takeover target Corus was laying off thousands. Critics charge that Mittal's largesse inhibited Blair from stepping in to save Corus.

name: Billionaires
bio: Munger is less famous—and less wealthy—than his partner Warren Buffett, but he&#39s still an integral part of Berkshire Hathaway. Munger met Buffett in 1959 and soon began investing in Berkshire. He also owns big stakes in discount retailer Costco Wholesale and legal-news publisher Daily Journal Corp.

name: Billionaires
bio: Daughter of tireless salesman Curtis Carlson (d. 1999) who invested $50 to start Gold Bond Trading Stamps in 1938, built into marketing, travel, hospitality conglomerate that includes Radisson Hotels, T.G.I. Friday's. Marilyn placed in charge of company in 1998, sister Barbara Carlson Gage retains significant stake in firm. Sizable Carlson Companies travel segment struggling along with rest of industry after September terrorist attacks.

name: Billionaires
bio: Owns Aruze, Japan's largest manufacturer of Pachislot, a kind of slot machine. Hurt recently by competitors' new and more successful products. Profits are expected to fall by 46% for the year ending in March, 2002. One of its game development subsidiaries declared bankruptcy in October. The company still has a 30% market share but Okada's ray of hope may lie elsewhere. He is partnering with American Steve Wynn to develop a casino resort in Las Vegas slated for a 2004 opening.

name: Billionaires
bio: Prince Albert turned 18 last June, instantly becoming one of the world's most eligible bachelors and Forbes' youngest billionaire. That's when he inherited one of the world's oldest fortunes, based on extensive landholdings, real estate, castles, works of art and businesses. Until his coming of age, his inheritance had been ably managed by his mother, Princess Gloria.

name: Billionaires
bio: Berg forged a career in Silicon Valley real estate, first as a loan processor, then a mortgage broker. Took warrants, stock in lieu of rent from fledgling tech companies. With his Mission West Properties real estate trust he is now one of the area's most powerful landlords. Still, with vacancy rates approaching 20%, the market is hurting.

name: Billionaires
bio: Onetime banker now a savvy investor. Bozano sold his Banco Bozano Simonsen to Spain's Banco Santander Central Hispano in 2000 for a reported $550 million. Last June he sold some of his nearly 20% stake in regional Brazilian jetmaker Embraer. As of mid-February, Embraer stock had tumbled nearly 50%.

name: Billionaires
bio: The king of Thai agri-business, Chearavanont turned a humble vegetable seed and animal feed business into billions.  Last year’s bovine outbreaks, like mad cow disease, only strengthened demand for Thai chicken products, resulting in a 23% increase in sales.  Dhanin has also been diligently paying off debt at his CP Food and TelecomAsia businesses, boosting their share prices.   This year he’s making plays in emerging markets like Cambodia, Vietnam, Burma and India.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founded in 1969 with a single drugstore, the Jean Coutu Group now runs more than 500 outlets in eastern Canada and New England under the Brooks and Jean Coutu banners. Expansion continues: In December the Group bought 80 Osco pharmacies in Massachusetts from the Albertson's supermarket chain for $240 million. Tightfisted with suppliers but gives generously to developing countries, battered women and the homeless.

name: Billionaires
bio: High school dropout, ex-Marine, built own TV tower with $1,500: "Just trying to get a good picture." Acquired cable franchises and built Cablevision Industries, which he sold to Time Warner in 1996 for $2.8 billion. Now owns AOL stock.

name: Billionaires
bio: Norway’s lone billionaire this year. He and his father opened their first discount supermarket together in the late 1970s, later merging it with Swedish retailer ICA. Two years ago the company entered a joint venture with supermarket giant Royal Ahold. Hagen now chairs ICA Ahold. Also has stakes in Storebrand, Norway’s largest insurer and Orkla, part-owner of brewer Carlsberg. Reportedly owns one of the biggest sailboats in Europe and his own island in the Caribbean.

name: Billionaires
bio: Enron's former president left that company in 1996, long before scandal struck. Saw no future in Enron's energy trading and derivatives, but rather in hard assets like pipelines and power plants. Good move. Now owns 20% of Kinder Morgan, which controls 30,000 miles of pipeline delivering 10 billion cubic feet of natural gas a day. Kinder pays himself just $1 a year.

name: Billionaires
bio: In 1997 Alicia Koplowitz decided to branch off on her own and sold her share of the family firm, Fomento de Construccciones y Contratas, to her older sister, Esther, for $800 million.  She established several investment arms (Morinvest, Omega Capital) and put her money in solid companies like Banco de Bilbao y Vizcaya, Endesa, Acerinox  and Telefonica.  Her careful investments have paid off, making her richer than her sister and the wealthiest woman in Spain today.

name: Billionaires
bio: With cousin George Roberts runs LBO firm Kohlberg Kravis Roberts of "Barbarians at the Gate" fame. Now shy of corporate-raider image, prefers to hold companies for eight-to-nine year range with higher proportion of equity than was customary in 1980s.

name: Billionaires
bio: Weathered the Asian downturn and emerged with a media distribution network that is turning heads in Asia. Krishnan also has two communication satellites orbiting in space. More than 2 million Malaysians subscribe to Maxis, Krishnan's cellular phone service. A half-million more get their daily dose of CNN from his satellite television network. Content is next. Krishnan owns 800 movie titles and is launching a Mandarin-language movie channel to air them. Look for much more from Krishnan, 63. This year he plans to list his cell phone and satellite company and is looking to expand outside of Malaysia. Krishnan has an M.B.A. from Harvard and got his start as an oil trader.

name: Billionaires
bio: Plumber's son from Long Island now a buy-and-hold investor with his own investment bank, Invemed Associates.  Made name for himself in 1968, taking Ross Perot's Electronic Data Systems public at 118 times earnings.  Eclectic holdings include stakes in restaurants (Tricon), insurance (Choicepoint), textiles (Unifi) and manufacturing (General Electric).  Credits success to humble roots: "I had a major advantage. I was raised poor."

name: Billionaires
bio: Brothers Steven and Mitchell broke away from dad's real estate business. Launched Danaher Corp. in 1982, named after favorite Montana trout stream. Created manufacturing conglomerate: tools, components, process-environmental controls. Rapid growth trhough aquistions, recent purchases: Lifschultz Industries, Microtest, United Power Corp. Seven billion dollar deal turned down by Copper Industries in August.

name: Billionaires
bio: Brothers Mitchell and Steven broke away from dad's real estate business. Launched Danaher Corp. in 1982, named after favorite Montana trout stream. Created manufacturing conglomerate: tools, components, process-environmental controls. Rapid growth trhough aquistions, recent purchases: Lifschultz Industries, Microtest, United Power Corp. Seven billion dollar deal turned down by Copper Industries in August.

name: Billionaires
bio: With cousin Henry Kravis runs LBO firm Kohlberg Kravis Roberts of "Barbarians at the Gate" fame. Firm now shy of corporate-raider image, prefer to hold companies for eight-to-nine year range with higher proportion of equity than customary in 1980s.

name: Billionaires
bio: Spent early years in Illinois housing prject. Peddled insurance to pay for college tuition, company's top salesman by senior year of college.  Since then worked in construction, oil, telecom. Founded Excel 1988 as Avon-like multilevel organization. Independent sales representatives sell long-distance phone service, recruit new reps. Teleglobe bought Excel 1998, merged with Canadian telecommunications and media giant BCE in 2000.

name: Billionaires
bio: A master of the buffet table, Bellon transformed his family's small Marseilles-based ship catering business into a global food service powerhouse with $10.5 billion in annual sales.  Last May Bellon's Sodexho Alliance bought out its U.S. partner, Marriott, in a $1.1 billion deal intended to broaden its North American presence.

name: Billionaires
bio: Botin is a fourth-generation banker who heads Banco Santander Central Hispano, Spain's biggest bank in terms of assets ($345 million). Net profits rose only 10% last year, compared with 25% in 2000.  BSCH is being affected by the economic crisis in Argentina where it's Banco Rio de la Plata is the country's second-largest private bank. Rio de la Plata  carried $7 billion of loans outstanding at the end of 2001, and BSCH has set $1.14 billion aside to cover its investment should it have to cut its losses and pull out of Argentina. In addition to BSCH, the Botin family also owns over 10% of Spanish domestic bank  Bankinter.

name: Billionaires
bio: Survived a tough year for luxury goods, in part because only 18% of sales came from the U.S. Scored a publicity coup with the publication of Bulgari Connection, a jewelry heist novel commissioned by Bulgari that included 30  mentions of the brand’s name. Launching new marketing campaign featuring Brazilian supermodel Gisele Bundchen. Paolo is chairman, brother Nicolo is vice chairman. Together they own 52% of Bulgari. Nephew Francesco Trapani is chief executive.

name: Billionaires
bio: The lumber industry giant made his mark by buying up California timberland on the cheap during 1980s recession. Now trying to forge a peace with clear-cutting opponents.

name: Billionaires
bio: This particularly media-shy billionaire made his fortune literally out of dust. He managed and expanded the mechanical engineering company GEA founded by his father in 1920, which initially specialized in the manufacturing of dust removal systems, and took the company public in 1989.   Happel sold his share of GEA for some $1 billion in 1999 and retired to tax paradise Switzerland, where he runs Luserve AG, a financial consulting firm. He apparently also owns Fregate Island, a luxury tourist paradise in the Seychelles.

name: Billionaires
bio: He took over his father's broadcasting company in 1981, and moved into satellite television several years later. He sold his United States Satellite Broadcasting Company to General Motors' Hughes Electronics in 1999; a proposed deal to sell the company to Charles Ergen's Echostar is now under scrutiny.

name: Billionaires
bio: Texas trial lawyer struck gold in the Texaco-Pennzoil case of 1987. Estimated fee: $345 million. Made millions more handling personal injury cases.

name: Billionaires
bio: Princeton graduate serves as president and chief executive of insurance outfit Progressive Corp. Passionate philanthropist, supports Princeton, Case Western U. and the Guggenheim.

name: Billionaires
bio: The Wharton grad started building his empire with $60 million he received for a contact-lens design in 1971. He later sold his Metro Mobile cellular phone company to Bell Atlantic for $2.6 billion; now he and his family hold large stakes in Verizon, natural-gas distributor Southern Union.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of John Willard Marriott Sr. (d. 1985), who started with a Washington, D.C. root beer stand in 1927 and opened first Marriott hotel in 1957. Now more than 2,000 properties worldwide. Harvard M.B.A. Richard is chairman of Host Marriott, the real estate arm spun off in 1993.

name: Billionaires
bio: A year ago Wales' richest man was giddily hiring engineers away from slumping Nortel Networks for his new Canadian-based March Networks and Mitel Networks. He has since toned down the tech enthusiasm, calling off plans to merge March and Mitel next year because of the soured market. Still maintains outsized optimism for a future filled with his Internet-enabled telephones and voice-recognition systems. In happier news, Matthews, who was knighted in October, completed a tony hotel and golf complex outside Ottawa, while his posh Celtic Manor resort outside London won the right to host golf's 2010 Ryder Cup.

name: Billionaires
bio: Auto mechanic's son dropped out of law school to start selling cars in 1958, built string of dealerships throughout native Texas. Started radio broadcaster Clear Channel Communications in 1972 with Lowry Mays. Has since added football team Minnesota Vikings and extensive western Americana collection to holdings.

name: Billionaires
bio: Turned from power to pigskins: Sold his energy producer Cogen Technologies to Enron for $1.5 billion, reinvested in new NFL team for his hometown of Houston.

name: Billionaires
bio: Infotech billionaire Shiv Nadar’s HCL group has grown from a garage startup in 1976 to a $650 million (revenues) IT conglomerate spanning 14 countries. Owns 78% of HCL Technologies, a software services provider. Like Premji, is now looking outside the U.S., his biggest market, for new business. Flits between California and Delhi, where he has homes. Also practices yoga.

name: Billionaires
bio: Scion of Pittsburgh's Mellon family. Arch conservative, backed investigations into Clinton scandals, publishes conservative newspaper Tribune-Review for Pittsburgh area.

name: Billionaires
bio: Grandfather founded Stryker Corp., massive medical-goods supplier. With his two sisters owns 25% of company. Jon a licensed arhchitect in Michigan, Florida.

name: Billionaires
bio: Grandfather founded medical-goods supplier Stryker Corp. Occupies sole family seat on board of directors. With younger brother and sister, controls 25% of company.

name: Billionaires
bio: Started FlightSafety, the world's largest pilot-training firm, in 1951. Took company public in 1968, sold to Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway in 1996.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman and CEO of United Overseas Bank pulled an upset victory against government-backed rivals at the Development Bank of Singapore by launching a successful takeover bid for Overseas Union Bank.  UOB is now the second-largest bank in Singapore, with a market capitalization of $12 billion.  The consolidation has gone smoothly, but at least 435 employees have been let go so far and there may be more lay-offs this year.  At 73, Wee remains a competitive tennis player and still enjoys a glass of good wine.

name: Billionaires
bio: With two siblings runs Ziff Brothers Investments, a private investment fund started with $2.1 billion from retired father's sale of Ziff-Davis Publishing empire (Car & Driver, Boating). Dad retired to Florida, handed sons control. Strategy: Hire Wall Street money managers to run various arms, bet on venture capital funds, tech stocks and corporate debt.

name: Billionaires
bio: With two siblings runs Ziff Brothers Investments, a private investment fund started with $2.1 billion from retired father's sale of Ziff-Davis Publishing empire (Car & Driver, Boating). Dad retired to Florida, handed sons control. Strategy: hire Wall Street money managers to run various arms, bet on venture capital funds, tech stocks and corporate debt.

name: Billionaires
bio: With two siblings runs Ziff Brothers Investments, a private investment fund started with $2.1 billion from retired father's sale of Ziff-Davis Publishing empire (Car & Driver, Boating). Dad retired to Florida, handed sons control. Strategy: Hire Wall Street money managers to run various arms, bet on venture capital funds, tech stocks and corporate debt.

name: Billionaires
bio: Troubled times for the Bass family. Sold $1.8 billion of Disney stock for margin call in late September; other telecom and high-tech investments have plunged. Father Perry built up the family empire from oil fortune made by uncle Sid Richardson. Tapped eldest son Sid to handle the money in 1968. Brother Robert broke from the family's business soon afterward. Smart move - sold out his Disney stake years ago, and made lucrative investments in oil and gas. Lee and Ed kept their money with Sid, though Ed reportedly wasn't involved in the September sale.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chicago cabbie moved to Indiana to start medical instruments firm. Created new cardiovascular catheter with $1,500 blowtorch, soldering iron and plastic tubing. Since then pacemakers, syringes, stents. Manufactured stent device used to treat Bob Dole's aneurysm; teaming up with rival Guidant to develop new stent. Varied interests: one-time John Mellencamp tour bus driver. His Broadway show Blast! pleased audiences last year.

name: Billionaires
bio: Started out as a metals trader, surviving the gangster wars in the aluminum industry. He emerged in control of Russian Aluminum, the country's dominant producer. Deripaska's holding company, Basic Element, controls Russian Aluminum (together with billionaire Roman Abramovich), automobile manufacturer GAZ, aircraft manufacturer Aviacor, timber companies, coal mines and financial companies. Last year Deripaska married the daughter of former President Yeltsin's chief of staff, who in turn married Yeltsin's daughter -- which means that Deripaska is now Yeltsin's grandson by marriage. As far as political connections go, this one is not bad.

name: Billionaires
bio: After agreeing to sell his USA Networks to Vivendi Universal, the William Morris mailroom graduate stands to become one of television's most powerful executives.

name: Billionaires
bio: Runs Brazil's largest food retailer, Grupo Pao de Acucar, which posted record profits of $166 million on revenues of $3.8 billion in 2000. Daughter Ana Maria is vice president of operations and has been reported as a potential successor. Abilio is an obsessive athlete; reportedly runs, swims or lifts weights several hours a day.

name: Billionaires
bio: Married into Pace Foods family, bought out in-laws in 1982 for $18 million and wife for estimated $95 million in 1991. Sold Pace to Campbell Soup for $1.1 billion in cash four years later. Invests in food companies through venture capital firm Silver Ventures. Funded San Antonio's Christus Santa Rosa Children's Hospital.

name: Billionaires
bio: Apple Computer cofounder continues to be renowned for role in the stylish firm, but animated-film studio Pixar accounts for bulk of his wealth.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son-in-law of Bud Walton, brother of Wal-Mart founder Sam Walton. Wife Ann Walton Kroenke and sister Nancy Walton Laurie inherited Wal-Mart stock after Bud's death in 1995. Stan develops real estate, but together husband and wife own pro basketball's Denver Nuggets and hockey's Colorado Avalanche.

name: Billionaires
bio: Lewis' status as one of the world's most elusive billionaires remains unchanged. A shrewd currency trader, Lewis is rumored to have made millions in the post-Sept. 11 turmoil. Sold a stake in Christie's for an estimated $350 million before the auction house scandals broke. A keen golfer, Lewis owns several upscale golf communities in Florida. Apparently paid over $1 million at a charity event to play a round of golf with Tiger Woods, a resident at one of his communities.

name: Billionaires
bio: With brother Kim Magness, two sons of TCI founder Bob Magness (d. 1996), inherited stock hoard now worth billions, thanks to TCI-AT&T merger. Brothers shun publicity, breed cattle. Gary recently married Sarah Siegel, head of women's-lingerie company SoLow and daughter of Celestial Seasonings' founder Mo Siegel.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of English immigrant grocer, raised in Portland, Ore. Sold magazines, lemonade during Depression. With physics master's from UCLA, founded, sold aerospace companies Spectrolab and Heliotex 1960s. Switched to biomedicine. In August sold insulin pump maker Minimed and private Medical Research Group to Medtronic for $3.8 billion. Pledged $270 million to USC, UCLA and Johns Hopkins.

name: Billionaires
bio: Sold wholesale grocery firm to friend, tennis partner Sam Walton in 1965 for cash and 5.6 million shares of Wal-Mart stock. Currently oversees McLane Group's grocery distribution, computer software, food manufacturing. Owner of Houston Astros.

name: Billionaires
bio: Youngest granddaughter of Prada founder Mario Prada. Took over luxury goods manufacturer with husband, Patrizio Bertelli, in 1978, but past year hasn’t exactly been de luxe: postponed much-anticipated initial offering; sold big stake in Fendi to LVMH for $262 million to raise cash to pay off debt; reportedly considering selling Jil Sander and Helmut Lang brands. Manhattan store opening was biggest architectural event since the Guggenheim reopened.
title: Owner, Fashion Designer

name: Billionaires
bio: Affable South African billionaire had little to cheer about this year. Controls Swiss-based luxury products group Richemont, whose brands include Cartier and Dunhill. Like other purveyors of the extravagant life, Richemont was hit hard by the economic downturn. Even before the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, operating profits were off 21% for the six months ending in September. Also owns stakes in South African companies Remgro, which has tobacco, mining and financial-services interests, and VenFin, a technology and telecom concern. Big golfer.

name: Billionaires
bio: While his country teeters on the brink of anarchy as its brutal civil war deepens, Colombia's only billionaire is still in business, albeit quietly. Steering clear of the press and staying out of his country's politics, Sarmiento and his son run the family's massive banking conglomerate Aval, while dabbling in telecommunications and real estate. It's lonely at the top, though; all four of the old man's daughters have left Colombia.

name: Billionaires
bio: Turned his 1965 Yale senior thesis into a $20 billion company, now a verb: 5 million packages FedExed every day. Used $80 million in family money and venture capital to launch company 1973. Decorated Marine Corps officer, cochairman of National World War II Memorial Campaign.

name: Billionaires
bio: Sobrato started as a residential broker in Palo Alto in the 1960s, then ventured into Silicon Valley commercial projects with Carl Berg. The two parted ways, and Sobrato now runs the business with his son, John Michael, overseeing 11 million square feet of commercial space, 470 acres of undeveloped land and some 5,000 apartment units throughout western states.

name: Billionaires
bio: Grandfather founded medical-goods supplier Stryker Corp. With her two siblings, Ronda and Jon Stryker, controls 25% of company, though firm's management is left to Chief Executive John W. Brown.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founder of Metrobank, the Philippines’ largest bank, with $7.5 billion in assets.   The bank recently strengthened its overseas remittance business and beefed up its technology in a bid to grow its customer base.  A true banker, Ty goes to the office every day dressed in a suit and tie.

name: Billionaires
bio: Grandfather John T. Dorrance invented process for condensed soup for Campbell Soup. Charlotte is an active philanthropist.

name: Billionaires
bio: Real estate mogul's Boston Properties owns gems in New York, San Francisco and Boston. Beloved media holdings New York Daily News and US News & World Report not as sparkling.

name: Billionaires
bio: With partner John Arrillaga bought cheap Silicon Valley farmland in the 1960s. Partners are now among the area's biggest landlords, with some 12 million square feet under management. With vacancies soaring, the duo's holdings have suffered like other developers.

name: Billionaires
bio: The third generation Azcarraga to lead Mexico's biggest TV network, Televisa, Emilio Azcarraga is facing more competition at home while securing more profits abroad. In Mexico, archrival Ricardo Salinas' TV Azteca is slowly but steadily eating into Televisa's market share. Having better luck in the U.S., thanks to revenue stream from highly successful and profitable Univision, whose popular soaps are produced by Televisa.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman of holding company Park Group. At age 47 Turkey's youngest self-made billionaire. Jump started career with the distribution and importation of auto parts. The 8,500-employee Istanbul-based conglomerate comprises 25 companies and is increasing stakes in mining companies this year as group shifts away from textiles to energy and mining. More acquisitions to come. Key to fortune is a soda ash reserve, which is generally used for making glass. Could actually benefit from problems in the Middle East if U.S. businesses, which are big soda-ash suppliers to that region, pull out. Other holdings include airport ground services, seaports and air transportation. Park's revenue has grown from an estimated $40 million in 1997 to $1 billion in 2001. Constructed three primary schools in Turkey and donated them to the Turkish government.

name: Billionaires
bio: The general partner of venture capital firm Kleiner Perkins Caulfield & Byers made early and lucrative bets on Amazon, Sun and Netscape. Soured on the tech mania, calling the bubble "the largest legal creation (and evaporation) of wealth in the history of the planet." Earned electrical engineering master's from Rice University, M.B.A from Harvard, followed by stints as Monsanto engineer, Intel salesman. Joined Kleiner Perkins 1980.

name: Billionaires
bio: Built family's scrap metal business into a cascade of holdings in media, utilities and oil, through holding companies Compagnie Nationale a Portefeuille and Geneva-listed Pargesa Holding.  Key investments include a 25% stake in German media behemoth Bertelsmann. Known as a workaholic who claims he'll never retire, Baron Frere nonetheless is a connoisseur of fine wine, and the co-owner (with French billionaire Bernard Arnault) of the Chateau Cheval Blanc vineyard.

name: Billionaires
bio: Education billionaire. Benesse Corp., his long-distance-learning business in Japan, has more than 4 million students and offers education courses to everyone from 1-year-old babies up to high school students preparing for college examinations. Also owns Berlitz, the language instruction and translation firm. Recently partnered with LeapFrog from California to develop Japanese versions of LeapFrog's hugely popular educational toys.

name: Billionaires
bio: Inherited valuable stakes in Amoco, other energy ventures from husband, John Murdoch Harbert III (d. 1995) who invested $6,000 of craps winnings to start construction business. Succeeded with high-risk ventures (airports, Mideast water supply systems). Bought coal reserves in Kentucky, Tennessee 1970s; sold for stake in Amoco during energy crisis. Son Raymond watches fortune. Marguerite needlepoints and hunts.

name: Billionaires
bio: The fourth Viscount Rothermere, Jonathan Harmsworth, faced his first real test as chairman of Daily Mail and General Trust in 2001 as advertising revenues took a sharp dip post Sept. 11. He weathered the storm well -- circulation for Daily Mail and The Mail on Sunday rose despite an increase in cover price.

name: Billionaires
bio: Grandson of William Randolph Hearst (d. 1951), media tycoon who built nation's largest newspaper chain. William III broke away from family business, now partner in tech venture-capital firm Kleiner Perkins, on boards of AtHome, Com21, Viewpoints Datalabs. Hearst empire today: 12 dailies (including "houston Chronicle"), 16 magazines (Harper's "Bazaar," "Cosmopolitan"), TV, cable programing (ESPN, Lifetime).

name: Billionaires
bio: Land developer and owner of Sinclair Oil is benefiting from Salt Lake City Olympics. His new Snowbasin ski resort will host downhill events. Also owns Sun Valley ski resort. Guests at this year's Olympics can stay at his palatial Grand American hotel, recently opened in downtown Salt Lake City.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former professor Jacobs now CEO of cell-phone giant Qualcomm, begun in 1985, grew rapidly thanks to key technology, code division multiple access. Stock took a hit after Enron-wary analysts questioned the wireless company's accounting, which the company promptly defended.

name: Billionaires
bio: This working mother of four continues to run the family-owned companies that make up the $6.5 billion (sales) Axel Johnson Group, founded by her great-grandfather. Last year saw Axel Johnson launch a fourth major division, AxFast BV, a commercial and retail real estate company in Sweden.

name: Billionaires
bio: New Delhi native considered the man with the "golden touch." He cofounded Sun Microsystems and is a general partner in venture capital firm Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers. Hit tough times recently: his ExciteAtHome went bankrupt.

name: Billionaires
bio: Runs leading Spanish construction group Fomento de Construcciones y Contratas, $3.4 billion (sales) builders of bridges, highways, commercial properties, water treatment plants and more. She owns 29% of the company her father founded in 1944. Esther was in the news last summer when over 20 paintings and sculptures valued at some $65 million (works by Goya, Foujita, Pissarro, Juan Gris and Pieter Brueghel) were stolen from her Madrid apartment in one of Spain's biggest art thefts.

name: Billionaires
bio: Not just any harpsichord-playing, ex-New York City cabbie can raise enough money to start a hedge fund. Fewer still could see their fund perform better than Kovner's Caxton Corp. Also has invested in the New York Sun, a Conrad Black-led venture slated to launch this spring.

name: Billionaires
bio: The Liu brothers developed a humble quail and chicken breeding business into an animal feed empire with an estimated $1.2 billion in sales and 6% of the Chinese market. In 1995, the brothers split the family business: East Hope, run by Liu Yongxing in Shanghai, and New Hope, run by Liu Yonghao in Sichuan. Yongxing is rumored to be investing in the metal industry, while Yonghao diversified into real estate. The brothers are also the largest shareholders in Minsheng Bank, China's first private bank, and are making plays in the insurance market. While hardly glamorous, the animal feed business has made these brothers the wealthiest citizens in China.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of John Willard Marriott Sr. (d. 1985), who started with a Washington, D.C. root beer stand in 1927 and opened the first Marriott hotel in 1957. Now more than 2,000 properties worldwide: Willard Jr. (Bill) took over as CEO in 1972 and now heads Marriott International, the hotel management part of the empire.

name: Billionaires
bio: The former coffee trader from New Guinea founded vineyard Rosemount Estates in 1969 with his teenage children. The family toiled on weekends and holidays to plant the first 50 acres, only finally producing wine in 1974. Last year Rosemount merged with Southcorp., Australia's largest premium wine producer, in a deal that gave the Oatleys some 100 million shares plus $450 million in cash. Son-in-law Keith Lambert now runs Southcorp.

name: Billionaires
bio: With partner John Arrillaga bought cheap Silicon Valley farmland in the 1960s. Partners are now among the area's biggest landlords, with some 12 million square feet under management. With vacancies soaring, the duo's holdings have suffered like other developers.

name: Billionaires
bio: In a year that saw Argentina become the world headquarters of economic turmoil, "Don Gregorio" seems to be the last man standing among the country's billionaires. Just barely. The once-bulletproof Argentinian energy business could be hurt further by a new tax on oil exports. It's no wonder the company's NYSE-listed stock is trading near its 52-week low.

name: Billionaires
bio: Milwaukee native got start in insurance business selling policies at dad's car dealership, 1964. Founded Aon, Irish for unity, in 1987; serves as chairman and chief executive. Now operates in more than 120 countries, $2 billion in annual revenue. Ryan is football fan: has 20% stake in pro football's Chicago Bears, big donor to Northwestern University, where he played football freshman year on scholarship.

name: Billionaires
bio: The widow of banking billionaire Edmond Safra, who died in a fire in his Monaco apartment in November 1999. More than half of Safra's estate - at least $3 billion - went to charity, but Lily's share makes her a billionaire.

name: Billionaires
bio: Schneider National kept on truckin' despite higher fuel costs, lower demand. He built his father's Green Bay-based trucking business into one of the nation's largest truckload carriers ($3.1 billion revenue). The market downturn forced him to put off plans to spin off Schneider Logistics, a high-tech shipping management operation.

name: Billionaires
bio: Earned civil engineering degree Colorado State U., 1953. Worked way up corporate ladder at construction giant Peter Kiewit Sons'; took over after Kiewit Jr.'s death 1979. Expanded into telecommunications with MFS Communications 1987; sold to WorldCom for $15.4 billion 1996. With investor group led by high school pal Warren Buffett, bought and took private MidAmerican Energy, 2000. Chairman, director and significant stakeholder at Level 3. Fisherman, hunter. Known for philanthropic efforts in education, civic projects.

name: Billionaires
bio: Elected in January 2001, Thailand’s billionaire prime minister narrowly escaped death two months later when a Thai Airways jet blew up moments before he boarded.  Last August he was also acquitted of charges that he concealed millions of dollars in assets while deputy prime minister in 1997.  Made his fortune prior to becoming a politician with Shin Corporation, a telecom holding company.  A former police officer, with a Ph.D. from Sam Houston University in Texas, he was welcomed by President Bush at the White House in December. Thaksin is also a former board member at the Carlyle Group, the high-powered private equity firm which boasts former president George Bush and other former high-ranking U.S. government officials as advisors.

name: Billionaires
bio: Stock in Check Point Software, Shwed's corporate security firm, hit the skids when the company barely met its fourth quarter projections in January. Shwed is hardly worried--the $8 billion (market cap) company still posted $322 million in profits, a 46% jump over last year. This year Check Point is expanding from the corporate market to mobile phone and broadband security. In December Check Point blazed a path into the home office and consumer market with the $300 S-Box, a small firewall that plugs into a PC. Last year the 34-year old bachelor hosted a corporate retreat in South Africa that included dancing, gambling and safari excursions.

name: Billionaires
bio: The fifth wife and widow of legendary publisher Axel Springer, founder of one of Germany's leading publishing groups (conservative daily Die Welt and tabloid Bild Zeitung). She owns 50% of Axel Springer Verlag, which is being dragged down by ad slump, increased paper prices and restructuring costs. The $2.5 billion (sales) company posted a net loss for 2001 of $146 million, compared with net profits of $75 million a year before. Friede Springer has won several awards for her contributions to society, including the Leo Baeck Prize from Germany's Jewish community for her efforts to rebuild German-Jewish relations and Axel Springer's continuing support of Israel.

name: Billionaires
bio: Grandfather John T. Dorrance invented process for condensed soup, leading to fortune in Campbell Soup Co. Hope's son Archibold runs Campbell's Godiva Chocolate division, only family member still working for firm full time.

name: Billionaires
bio: Father founded sign company 1935. As youngster ran neighborhood snow shoveling service: "Took a crew out. I was the seller and they were the workers." Next, teen ad salesman. Left U. of Nebraska for Merchant Marine Academy. Graduated, took over dad’s billboard business 1946. Big break: Holiday Inn contract. Sold Whiteco Outdoors to Chancellor for $960 million in 1998. Whiteco Industries still owns billboards in China; hotels (Marriott, Holiday Inn). Self-professed technology dinosaur launched Profile Systems 1997 to monitor billboard lighting via satellite.

name: Billionaires
bio: Woo resigned from the family's Wheelock & Co. in 1995 and in 1997 made a failed bid to become Hong Kong's first chief executive. The family still owns 60% of the shipping and real estate company. As chairman of the Hong Kong Trade Development Council, Woo has had a busy schedule selling the economic merits of Hong Kong, "My trips were tough, 50 cities in 50 days."

name: Billionaires
bio: Turned his parents' small clothing store into Fast Retailing, Japan's answer to the Gap. Like that much beleaguered U.S. retailer, Fast Retailing is experiencing the pains of slow retailing, due to intense competition and saturated markets. Yanai's net worth is down from $4.8 last year to $1 billion. Expanding into China next. Also announced plans to venture into organic vegetables sales.

name: Billionaires
bio: The family's construction and property-development company is one of Asia's best managed. Knack for clinching lucrative government deals in Malaysia keeps company stock steady through economic downturn: YTL Group has contracts for several large-scale projects in Malaysia, including supplying cement for the rail link to connect the country's international airport to the federal capital as well as for infrastructural works, bridges, bypasses and hospitals. Also has a lucrative deal to supply power to the Malaysian government. Making aggressive moves overseas in an attempt to diversify beyond Malaysia. Group's Pangkor Laut Island resort considered one of Asia's top honeymoon destinations.

name: Billionaires
bio: Descendants of Spanish aristocrats. The family controls Ayala Corp., the largest conglomerate in the Philippines, with diverse businesses that include real estate development, water supply, banking, automobile distribution and food production. Ayala operates in a country where 37% of the population still lives below the poverty line. Family's Ayala Foundation sponsors social development programs in an effort to "uplift the life of the Filipino poor." Don Jaime, a world-class photographer, is the patriach. Since 1995 his two sons, Jaime Augusto and Fernando, oversee day-to-day operations.
